earnestly beseche thee article day ouer christendō controuersious great temerite selfe willed heretiks raised vp diligently labour trauaile supremacy suche say truthe effecte al depende vpon protestantes lutheran zwinglians anabaptistes trinitaries sectes otherwise mutuall mortall enemitie emonge themselues conspire againste primacy see apostolike good resolution one pointe staieth setleth conscience sure stronge anker insurgies tempestes foresaide rablemēt sectes schismes contrary wise one circumuented deceaued article caried tossed raging whaues flouddes euery errour heresy without staie settling euen owne errours reporte grecian forsaking vnitie romaine churche first arrians defying popesozo lib 3 cap 8 socrat li 2 cap 15 may appeare letter eusebius greate arrian felowes iulius pope fell macedonian nestorian eutychians monothelites iconomaches diuers greate heresy eche heresy breeding great number sectes conspiring see apostolike vntil last proceding heresy heresie diuers recō ciliations romaine see comming betwene staied longe time god highe vengeaunce ensewed fel turkish captiuitie ô lamentable case remayne day reporte african falling vnitie romaine seeopta li 2 first donatistes despising iudgemente pope melchiades first springe heresy might haue bene stopped geuen eare chiefe pastour falling pelagiansvictor de persequut vandal soone arrians conqueste wandalles became time infidelles daie continue reporte laste heresy northe bohemian fyrstein parua confessio de coena domini nowe luther scholers whiche wythin fewe yeares maister yet liuing flourisshing wente farre hym pronounced open writyng heretiques archeheretiques yet nowe meane sacramentaries whome luther defyed beare greatest swaye sectes ende heresy wyll except abandonne tyme hungarie lifelande maye lesson vnto vsstaphylus apolo part 3 whiche luther heresye bothe fallen awaye romaine churche romaine empire one turkes handes moscouites leaue forayne countres triall separat selues see apostolike owne domesticall affayres maye serue v sufficient example time kinge henry 8 first banisshed pope authoritie englande kinge parliament thought though erroneously imported schisme heresy thought likewise suche sorte prouide people shoulde fall errours newe lutheran sacramentary religion kinge parliament lesse abhorred turkery issewe worlde knoweth england pitie greuously feeleth immediatly bookes came thicke abrode well lutheran zwinglian secte people fell fast contentation liking king fayne make diuers streight lawes actes parliament repressing heresy actes ād monumentes fol 553 yea forbidde common people reading bible sate owne person iudgement vpon lamberte sacramentary neither lutheran zwinglians onely swarmed realme anabaptistes also twelue sayed anabaptistes burned aboute one tyme nowe thoughe king henrye altered matter fayth sauing primacie onely kepte constantlye catholike fayth otherwise though suppressing abbey would suffer religiouse men vowed chastitye marie yet hys death minoritye hys sonne kinge edwarde lawes made towching matter religion sauing supremacie repelled abolisshed new religion realme set forthe though religion nowe vsed much conformable yet many thinges muche diuersit • e among mariage priestes colour king edwardes day acte parliament nowe haue church lawe lawe realme verie lawe godpsalm 75 saieth vouete reddite make vowe perfourme paule saieth habentes damnationem quia primam fidem irritam fecerunt 1 tim 5 incurring damnation haue broken first promise againe first yeare gratious queene acte parliament making consecrating bisshoppes made 28 kinge henrye reuiued yet bisshoppes ordered accordinge acte according acte made kinge edwarde dayes repelled quene marye reuiued sayde first yeare yf say defecte nowe supplied let yet remember parliament churche bisshoppes catholike bisshoppes ordered manner fasshion catholike church euer vsed thys considered lamented thinges wheras acte parliament geue anye sufficient warrant discharge man catholike faythe wheras yt aswel king hēries dayes acte parliament euer church christendome sithens christened taken playne open heresie denie reall presence christes bodye sacramente aulter maynteining heresie acte parliamēt god thancked neither king edwardes tyme tyme graciouse soueraygne ladie quene nowe yet doe men teache preache writing defend maynteine saied greate abhominable heresie many shewe warrante anye temporall spirituall lawe euer hath bene made englande countrey christendome acknovvledgeth prince supreame head beside englande lutherus contra art louauienses tom 2 magdeb praefat cent 7 caluinus osee 1 et amos 7 iacob acontius stratagē satanae lib 3 see leafe 15 andreas modre de ecclesia lib 2 c 10 haue spoken shewe true haue saied neuer redresse errour heresie staie men gone vnitie see apostolike welspring fountaine vnitie catholike faith touching question supremacie haue hand wel consider shall find doe agree either protestantes selues pointe make prince supreme head churche neither agree luther selfe scholers denie primacie caluin scholers sacramentaries caluin saieth blasphemer called king henrie head church one scholers iacobus acontius booke dedicated queenes mai blameth openly ciuil magistrate maketh selfe iudge controuersies aduise commaundeth doctrine published suppressed nowe caluins scholers owne countriemen haue taken forth lesson haue auouched bookes printed publisshed world woman neither head church realme againe manie protestant though pope haue chiefe gouernement like true doctrine yet thinke meete conuenient one person ecclesiasticall maie haue supreme gouernement matter church also considered wordes othe nowe tendered mainteining prince supremacie king henry king edwardes day certaine addition greatest importance ciuil prince specially person woman wise conuenient sense applied meane wordes supreme gouernour aswell spirituall ecclesiasticall thinges cause temporall large ample wordes neither foresaied king time put othe yet bene tolerable person men capable spiritual gouernmēt frō woman expresly nature scripture excluded nowe wordes saie colourable pretext excused neither inough saie iniunctions doe quenes maiestie entendeth take vpon king henrie father king edward brother euer lesse must also considered successours may take vpon largenes wordes iniunction limit acte parliament whether either scripture good doctrine ecclesiastical sufficient satisfie conscience refuse especially othe doth exclude apostolical see generall councelles also though plaine wordes yet effect excluding ecclesiastical authoritie al foren person prelate doth adioyne foresaied newe addition lesse probable lesse tolerable parte former othe therefore certaine protestant name reputation tendred othe commission haue refused yea well trow supreme gouuernement liked minister withstand quenes iniunctions touching order semely apparell c thus ye perceyue gone constante setled doctrine church touching primacy agree among selues either pointes thys article supremacy neither shal euer fynd anie cause good sufficiente contentation constancye doctrine vntill returne thither whence first departed see apostolike al people nation hath euer reuerenced honoured ought al doe whence britaines saxon receiued first christian faith returne god mercie graunt v shall blessed pleasure amen put hand one queenes cōmissioners redresse saied disorder vnlesse hath doth maītein many thing beside yea cōtrary lawes order realm late set forth cōcerning mater ecclesiasticall wel knowē proued regiment vvhich horn doth • touchethere therfore cause many thing considered firste christe lefte one rule whole churche steade tyme tyme vnto ende worlde secondly one saint peter apostle bisshoppes rome successours thirdly albeit bisshop rome vniuersal gouernment ouer whole yet euer patriarche englande whole weste church hath muche doe patriarche patriarkshippe nothing intermedle v pope patriarche yet supremacy ciuil prince iustified whereof capable especiallye woman must remayne spiritual man beside catholikes sayno regiment horne defēdeth among al sectes sauing england neuer suche presidēte heretofore catholike churche present except england neither emonge lutheran zwinglians swenckfeldians anabaptistes secte daye raygneth rageth worlde none saye agnise cyuil prince supreame gouernour al cause spiritual temporal last al say fekenham wil also saye euen horne selfe answere retreyteth farre backe assertion supreame gouernment cause spirituall temporallm horne himselfe denieth supremacie al cause • cclesiastical whiche state keye whole question plucketh prince chief principal matter cause ecclesiasticall shall plainely shewe owne woordes premiss true owre syde abundantly proued better proued occasion shall serue nothing effectually brought horne ye shal euidently perceiue processe stragleth quyte al point besetting himselfe study endeuor proue neither greatly hyndereth oure cause much bettereth neither maister fekenham catholike greatly contende whiche done prince may medle deale cause ecclesiasticall meaning true dothe yt nothing reache home pointe haue bene debated vpon much labour vaynely idlelye employed tediouse infynite talke bablinge purpose owte matter whiche ought speciallye haue bene iustifyed therefore impudente facing bragging say hath proued like regiment deny father councels continual practise churche worthy see iolye pollicy man howe euen correspondent fellowe protestantsthe vneuen dealing protestant iewel restrayneth catholikes 600 yeres extraordinary newe founde prescription owne embarringe al later proufes yet selfe meane tyme runneth large almoste one thowsande yeares later shrynkinge hither thyther taking tagge ragge heretike catholik fortifying false assertion wise trade man kepeth also resolue fekenham setle conscience specially stayeth self vpon platina nauclerus abbas vrspergensis sabellicus aeneas pius volaterranus fabian polichronicon petrus bertrandus benno cardinal durā dus p aemilius martinus poenitentiarius polidorus virgilius lyke self declareth otherwhere place also confesseth nowe catholiques refuse catholique writer matter haue cause doe yet matter importance beside losse al tēporal relief besyde bodily death importeth also euerlasting damnation catholikes case stande horne fellowes beare v hande reason would haue fetched substance proufes much higher yea within 600 yeres whervnto strayne binde v catholikes haue already performed iewel substance matter onely euen iustifying precise wordes wherein iewel hathe framed foolish wylynes wylye foolyshnes state question meane wordes head church vniuersall busshop fekenham nowe syr would reuel yow lyke rhetorike require yow proue father writing within sayde 600 yeares expresse wordsa challenge horn supreame heade gouernour cause spiritual temporal haue bene geuen attributed ciuil magistrate againe temporal bolde leaue plainelye bluntelye goe worke yowe haue done grindall iewel yowr pewefellowes remoue glorious glittering pecoks taile call figge figge horne horne saye moste truely ye lorde byshoppe therefore firste bisshoppe sewte race consequentlye horn firste b race see vvinchester fortresse first faith annexed ven bede par 2 cap 13 8 protestantes vvōderfully trobled questiō continual succession bisshops byshoppe able shewe whome yee ordinarilie succede anye good accustomable eyther vocation consecration whiche point necessarilie required bishoppe apostle luther caluin lacking haue otherwhere sufficientlye proued though deepe silence thinke wisedome vtterlie dissemble one answere therewith pressed meshed bewrapped therein coulde worlde wytte saye thereto answering wist nere point holde yea beza faine last assemblie poisy silence cō fesse inuincible truth let vocation good sound yet haue disabled self occupie roome either ought admitted forthwith ought ye remoued ye yoked ye pretende maried wel maintenāce therof many abhominable error case stand obstinately doubt heretike ye liue pretensed matrimonie madge al worlde knoweth colouring fleshly pleasure vnder name honorable sacramēt incest wretchedly prophaned vilained ye keep said madge face al worlde without shame whiche king henry day ye kepte hucker mucker lusky lane many sort especially cranmer occupied see cāterburie caried prety conie chest full hole nob might take ayer lecherie turned name vvedlockyou wil perchance stande defence pretensed mariage also heresy say heresy turne lecherie wedlock sorte haue late day turned vppon good fridaie pigge pike putting said pigge water saying goe pigge come pike referre olde canon father writinges especially augustine epiphanius philaster among heresy recite openly fellowes maintaine yf ye reiect poore catholiquesm horn fellovves accōpted heretikes apologie england apologia lat 8 pag 33 augustine epiphanius also yet trust owne famouse apologie whiche saith epiphanius nombreth fourscore heresy one man order priesthode marie augustine greater nomber concludeth residue heretikes ye wil denie ye mainteine heresy preaching teaching writing beare full open testimony haue iustifie cause wil happely forsake abandon augustine authoritie withal olde canon councels flye vnder defence brickle bulwarke actes parliament poore sely helpe miserable shift faith hang vppon acte parliamente contrary wel actes parliament euer holden englande canon father catholike churche strange wonderfull matter heare christian common welth matter faith parliament case ciuill prophane matter conuerted holie ecclesiasticall matter yea woorse laie men folde onely shepheards allreligion •• ered • ngland • gaīst 〈◊〉 vvhole cl • rgie therefore bounde learne catholique bisshoppes pastours may alter whole catholique religion maugre heades bishoppes whole conuocation trouble thing confounde togeather heauen earth yet let v see prouidence god men horn defend mainteine heresy bisshop anie lavve realme see apologie staphilus fol 81 relinquishing church would hang vpō parliament quite forsaken yea euen loked best helpe praye warrant acte parliament denie real presence christes bodie holie eucharistia anye parliament well heresie nowe quene mary king henry anye kinges dayes shewed contrarie doth luther first apostle schollers defie therefore detestable heretiques nowe concerning transubstantiation adoration well knowen thinke king edwardes dayes preaty legerdemaine played leafe putt printing neuer proposed parliamente parliamente haue preacher denye free necessitie baptizing child againe pray acte confirme vnlawful mariage doth point canonicall lawe stande force well nowe king henry day doth followe yee true bishoppe beside notoriouse yee colleages ordeined according prescripte wil say churche euen verye statute howe yee challenge selfe name lord bisshoppe winchester whereof bothe municipall ecclesiasticall lawe dothe woorthelye spoyle wherefore sayed let v dashe wordes reasonable man shall haue great cause quarell title fekenhams treatise 2 diuision horne booke deliuered vnto mee touching othe writen tovver london selfe confessed true title therof doth plainly testifie time parliamēt holden anno quinto q maiestie ianua 12 time litle thought haue soiourned winter follovving much lesse meant deliuer scruple stay cōscience writing resolued hand although would haue seeme haue published abroade cause wrot resolued hande yet trueth selfe reported tovver fellovves hearing statute moued assuraunce queenes royall povver would passe establissed conceiue immediately session commissioner shoulde sente vnto exact othe vvhereuppon readines withstande refuse duetie good subiecte 8 8 vntruth slā derouse without helpe reste may vsinge manye shiftes amongst continuallie quarell sophistication vvordes vvill ende vve might certainlye goe forvvarde pointes materiall vvoulde vvryte position assertion fourme proposition vvhiche coulde cause doe anye vvise yee vvoulde still stande vncertainelye graunting deniyng pleasure yea althoughe better agreemente dravve suche fourme assertion gaue vvrittng vnto gathered ovvne mouthe opinion yet vvoulde yee vvise stande reste one certainelye vsed still accustomed vvrangling wādring large vvhiche behauiour muche misliked mee coulde earnestly charge vvith inconstancie yee woulde sometimes denie yee graunted also graunte yee denyed muche pressed herevvith perceiuing frovvarde quarelling vvith plaine vvoordes statute coulde lenger couer euill meaning length require vvoulde put horn vntruths shedule made without helpe rest proue horn may gathered ye say yea haue sone forgottē late lessō circumstance enforced yow gather according owne rule specified againe ye say fekenham answered hand nothing obiecte semed resolued maner satisfied syr cal vpon yow yet ons againe remember former rule ye straitly vaynly charged fekenham yet ye seame somwhat better aduised mollifying matter wordes maner satisfied wise yt passed al good maner honesty vntruly make reporte cōtrary wel knowen neuer yelded vnto one pointe religiō neither courte yet manour else haue heape vntruthes packed vp together horne haue good meaning towards fekenham making within six line vntrue slanderouse report reuolte relligion receiued professed baptisme reuolte fayth christes catholike churche▪ reuolte al blessed sacrament vnity saide churche thereby become starke schismatike heretike horne selfe y horne good frendly meaninge towards fekenham thāketh yow nawght none hath espyed yow ye proferre muche wronge like sorte saying fekenhams frende stande yow made relation hope ye fekenhams conformity fekenhā vpō reporte frend repugnant seemeth made owne head furnishe forged tale withal bene true yow according owne rule set forthe truthe thereof obseruing dewe circumstance matter person tyme place incomparably passeth farre excedeth al forsayde vntruthes ye say fekenham shrinke cōfederats yow terme maliciously thē truely conferēce made westminster euer since conceiue feare constancy religion beseach yow good syr one point religion shrinke company cōference westminster matter wherin dissented whereas also hadde agreed vppon booke towching question controuersie betwene yow thē right honorable lord keaper great seale commaunded quene highnes name beginne reade booke first refused doe yet parte thought good disobey quenes highnes commaundemente therein thervppon offered himselfe beginne disputation lord keper would permit doe offence beseache yow hath fekenham cōmitted herein great worthy dashe penne shrynkinge religiō cal yow defence thereof openly proferre self put forthe first argumente booke set forth sayd conference disgracing depressing catholiks dothe yet geue commendation fekenham cause aboue sayde nothing towcheth suspicion inconstancy mambring religion ye vniustly doe fyne singular inuention ons againe must plucke yow horne cal yow home owne rule demaūde yow sir know yow towre fellowes haue conceiued feare proufe ye able make thereof ye haue spoken word ye haue writen ye haue set forth printe vewe sight worlde trowe good meaninge towardes fekenhā yea forsothe seeth withal honorable prelate yow thus stuff farse booke heape ouersights open vntruthes might passe forth residewe horne book sauing mētiō conferēce westmynster disputatiōs nothing neadful al much lesse parliamēt time cōference whol clergy whose iudgemēt haue bene case chieffest importāce vniformly agreed aswel vpō real presēce trāsubstantiatiō ād sacrifice also supremacy pope made hūble petitiōn became vocatiō aūciēt relligion might altered parliamēt although could neuer obtaine petition might read yet woulde nedes haue gonne forward disputationsthe catholikes suffred replie reason ben haue begonne chief principal point dependant accessory mēbers matter nothing touching faith withal haue suffred catholiks haue replied aduersaries whiche could suffered doe least aduersaries weaknes shuld would haue done dede daily doth god praised euidently openly haue b • ne disciphered disclosed wherin whether catholiks indifferently dealt beside prince authority religion horne hath taken place late rebellion flandersto come outragious enormity low country tongue expresse penne deciphre sufficiently extremity thereof men liuing vnder catholique moste clement moste mighty prince loyaltie profession suche neither reuerence religion consider clemencie feare power contrary open edictes proclamation abusing rare clemencie remitting therefore hath continued al garboiles trouble disorder free spoiles church chappelles yea monastery round townes beside haue done namely bruxels bruges lyle mount henaut arras douay towne el importance farre remember also hath remained free schismatical sermon towne whiche great towne brabant flanders beside said god onely praised therefore whose glory write towne vniuersitie aboue al townes al land moste spyted threatened rebellious protestantes reason doctours inquisitours whose rigour pretended cause malice god singular mercy speciall malice singularly preserued onely glorie shall haue sermon suche place time woulde saye figge edicte traiterouse brethern antwerp haue sticked openlie saye vnmanerlie talke meet clenly gospel schij • e op die conning haue woorde euer oure bruxels court octaues assūptiō lady special solemnitie chief church antwerp townby vvhat meanes nevv prechīg • entered first tovvne antvverp brother gouernors absence emboldened despite solēnity enkendeled xx august beīg tuesday toward euenīg antemne time betwene v vj clock began first certain boyes play pageāt mocking striking way derision image lady thē especially visited honored honorable memorial glorious assūptiō light behauiour boy som stirre made wel catholiks church factiō caluinists also thē assēbled catholikes fearing greater incōuenience began depart churche brother rumour therof increased much herevpō incontinētly margraue towne chief officer gouernours absence sone aduertised catholikes tumult like arise drew al hast church brother time become lordes church shut dores margraue notwithstāding length margraue going doore dore gat approching assemblie caluinists willed cōmaūded thē king name whose officer depart church interrupt god seruice begun thei answered thei came also god seruice sing psalmes honor place cōueniēt therfore many wordes passing betwen margraue number great increasing stil margraue departed church nothing preuailing neither faire wordes foule magistrate thus reiected vnhable deede withstande faction rebelles appeared well euen night holy brotherhode went druggery first song psalmes pretending cause meeting time psalmodie rushed great number people see gone againe remaine accompanie self present beginning tragedy coming chaunce towne afternone saw margraue gone churche psalmodie begonne past verely suppose threescore person assembled mary rushed continually greate number taried still six clock time foreward melodie sone ended proceeded sacrilege breaking image throwing downe aulters organes kind tabernacle well churche church monastery chappelles antwerpe stealing chalice spoiling cope breaking vppe seates robbing churche warden box well churche poore heerein reporte whiche sawe myne eye sainte iames churche spoyle outragiouse church al settle bench seates made aboute churche pillers aulters folke sitte kneele maner left whole one onelye excepted placed west ende churche diuers little scobbes box gathering poore scobbes lo onlye broken vp content visited chiefe deuotion reste remained whole vnspoyled shorte al night bene present thereat might well seme nox siciliana zelous brotherhood folowed chase lefte one churche antwerpe greate smal hunted vp good game caryed away fleshe good store chalice patens cruet golde siluer cope vestiments silke veluet fyne linnen course none came amisse tooke al good parte tooke founde shal speake library spoiled burned namely grey fryer abbye michael describe particularly horrible outragious sacrilege night eternal documēt ghospellike zele sacred brotherhood woulde require ful treatise selfe much haue shorthly touched may see ād palpably feele horne common sense remaine obedient subiects brethern 24 myles prince courte contrary expresse admonition magistrat present contrary law reason right conscience vnder pretence forsothe ghospels zele zele truly christes ghospell neuer feared great number committe open robbery thefte felony sacrilege treason let v procede noble strategeme way bringe preachinges within towne walles trow well deserued towne right worthy fauour libertye therefore thursdaye preached openly lady churche saterday burge churche required haue place al church preache first two fowre last catholiks church forebidden thē obtayned yet certain place new towne build new church great spede caluinists builded foure lutheran two much grounde gotte one nightes worke possible beastly beginning haue eyther long cōtinuance good ending shal see issue moneth august antwerp gant ypres valencene diuers town flādres hartoghēbuske lyre brabant diuerse town also hollād zelād throughout wel nere al low coūtres church wer robbed ād spoiled though outragiously vniuersally town antwerp storme sodayne spoiles somwhat asswaged ād stopped policy ād spedy resistāce yet new preachīgs took place al town ōly louain haue said excepted beīg ōly maidē toun importance al brabāt flandres free within many myle aboute lesse al schismatical preaching frō sacrilegious spoiles god haue said praised therefore procede soone sacrilege thei fel opē rebelliō whē al wēt foreward liked ministres persuasion townes began rebelle shut gate king souldiars haue iustice vpō church robber stay farder enormity prince cōmaūded admitted tournay valencens hartoghenbaske ād hassel lukelād tournay soone recouered protestātical rebelles subdewed valēcens held euē battery wals time catholiks driuē toune opēly would shew thē selues al monastery ouerthrowen church turned barn storehouse corne brethern antwerp enuying ioly liberty audacity valēceners attēpted diuers time obtayn like town also witness hereof tumult made grey fryer church 19 septēber prince orēge present skāt able stay spoyl renewed mary church moneth nouēbre whereof six next day hāged conte hochstrat thē prince orenge deputy burning great part grey fryer church cloister first sōday lēt last al opē manifest notorious rebelliō made caluinists antwerp 13 march last whē thei possessed artillery town plāted ordināce great maire strete called stoode armes prīce required opēly kayes gate ād town house banishmēt al religious person ād priest ād brefly cry thē wēt stretes de coopmās goet en papē bloet good marchāts ād blood priest say manifest clere ād euident witness caluinistes antwerp attēpted lesse rebelliō thē town valēcens practised dede notorious attēpt whole maner ende beginning thereof toward end book shall largely speak place remitte reader great sodayn ouerthrowe god hath geuē al trayterous attēpts ghospellīg protestāts haue wrought therein destructiō attēpted dominiō self heresy feare would longer haue ben winked perhaps repressed al first caluinists antwerp mayne force catholiks lutherās ioyning feate thē cōstrayned lay downe weapon crye viue • e roy god saue king sone vpon palmesonday towne valencenes taken king captaynes straight easter preacher driuen departe antwerpe al townes cyties lowe country newe church made pray king souldyars briefely al restored olde face coūtenāce nighe short time may wonderfully mercifullye miraculously god hath wrought herein neither rude penne able worthely expresse nether smal experience sufficiently report leaue therefore better time occasion exactly worthely chronicled lo horne obedience caluinistes low coūtres hear daily eares see eye truly experiēce hath wel shewed protestāts obey vntil haue power resiste whē faction stronger syde resiste bothe prelats pope laye bothe kinges keysars law gospel enforceth minister persuade persuasiō theodore beza caluins holy successour geneua villayne poltrot slewe duke guise prince capitain general authority hermannus knowen rennagate englande famous preacher italy open baudery lesse infamous towne hassel lukelande rebelled encouragement setting ministres time chiefe magistrats towne tournay season also rebelled sent ayde rebelles valēcens sped according desertes number ij aboute intercepted king souldyars slayne within twelue dayes christmas laste wel knowen namely first execution made taking valencenes aboute witsontyde laste minister themselues chiefe authours lōge obstynat rebellion towne supreme gouuerment prince ouer cause ecclesiastical dere brethern horne caluinistes doe acknowledge practise renewe farder rebelliō peace god churche owne safty doe pray sauing poore honesty nede praye except harte also horne though penne condemne nowe purgation catholiksthe catholikes seditious subiects man falsly maliciously bloweth horne yt may seame good conueniente proufe quietnes obedience al 8 year hath ben realme one heare hath bene conuicted disloyalty worde dead concerning prince ciuil regiment wishe large ample honorable euer noble countreymans greate constantine albeit knowe quòd non sit tutum scribere contra eos qui possunt praescribere vvhye catholiks shuld borne vvithal yet matter conscience relligion wherein onely stande poore catholikes moste humblye vppon knee desire highnes may moste lowlye submission craue require borne withall yf vppon sodayn withoute sure substantial groundes abandon faith baptized assured al auncetours al maiesties noble progenitor yea owne noble father king henry eight yea faith clerkly booke hath pythely defended therby atchieued transported hereditary successionthe queenes title defender faith worthy title style yet remayning highnes defendour faith disobedience matter yf thing v worthy name wherein haue said first principal obedience must wayt stoutlye booke auouche displaceth christe owghte onely enioye whereas ye moste vntruely saye heere make pope god earth maister gilbie saieth make prince god attributing wrong title wherin christ wil haue cōpartener surely make god pope sometimes perhappes good man neyther yet reuerence office authoritie christe amplie honorablie gaue preseruation vnitie quietnes church wisedome like truth also appeareth call pope archeretike rome naming man woordes liberallie wantonly cast doe wel comprehend peter clement holy martyr bishop anye promise wel blowen blast hansomly handeled like finenesse call archeretike supreme iudge ouer heretikes heresy hath already iudged patriarch archeritikes wisse well might fellon barre westmynster hall saue life mighte call iudge strongest theef doubtles prince side plea good youres ye say would haue pope raigne quenes place procedeth frō lik truth ād wisedom albeit pope autority euer chief matter eccleastical yet neuer much noddie say ād beleue pope ecclesiasticall good skil man hath logike correspondent diuinity hath browght v foorth faulty viciouse definitionthe definitiō supreme gouernour supreame gouernour hath chief gouermente thīg gouerned action may way properly belong subiect thing gouerned horn saith action belonge ende whereunto gouernour tendeth may wel althowgh haue chief gouerment al action thing gouerned suche action properly appertayne subiecte gouernour one man many ruler may doe dayly concurre whiche sense may euery one called supreame gouernours yf seruant maister son respect father yf father maister dwel city maior also father maisters cheif gouernour thing concerning ciuil gouernment city al prince chief supreame gouernour subiects otherwise prince doth intermedle father office duetifulnes dewe vnto son maister gouerment hath vppon seruantehow prince supreame head gouernour al persōs scholemayster gouerment schollers actiōs maister ship action doings mariner otherwise offende positiue lawes realme hath prince subiecte shal haue nede vse commen welth wherein subiects member said cōmen welth must hī obey much like spiritual mē also mēbers sayde cōmen welth ād therfore respect subiect prīce ād lawes true prīce supream gouernour al person aswel spiritual tēporal therfore also supreame gouernour al action wil follow thē action rehersed yea much lesse better vnderstanding whereof knowē comming christ kinges wer many christian kinges none many cōmen welthes wer christē cōmē welththende tē poral gouernmēt yet godly cōmō welth properly speke sauīg amōg iewes ciuil politik end final respect ciuil commēwelth vnder regimēt one moe person multitude cōmitteh thēself ordered ruled preserue thēselues al inward outwarde iniuries oppression enimies prouide saftie ād quietnes welth abundance prosperouse maintenance also ende tendeth reacheth ciuile gouernment preseruation tuition furtherance end chiefly serueth prince principal honorable person whole state thing common wel bound aide • pirituall povver suche haue receiued god large helpe faculty toward reason great authority tē poral sworde ioyne case requireth spiritual sword al good prince ād haue aiding assisting effectually take place supreame gouernement haue onlesse selfe spirituall man man master shippe neuer mariner maior neuer citizen principall gouernemente reasteth ciuill matter respecte haue sayed able make declaration vnto meanes may swere thereunto without commiting plaine manifest periurie part committed damnable sinne expresse woord god writen leuit cap 9 non periurabis nomine meo nec murderer murderer sleeth body sleeth soule one soule two soule prouoketh periurie owne soule also ministring occasion therof point othe whereunto presently swere without plaine manifest periurie foure following horne mutato nomine de te fabula narraturas whiche goeth couertlie vttered manie vntruthes althoughe sometime yee stoumble trueth againste youre rest fal plaine manifest vntruths least men shuld perceiue neuer required svvere therfore impudent kind dealing saie vvherunto presently required swere c none authoritie cōmission require othe neither might tender vnto without peril mie selfe cōmitted vnto honorable coūcel without whose order could attempt suche mattier haue alreadie shevved plaine matter although plainnesse speache thinke persvvaded cōscience highnes supreme gouernour well cause ecclesiastical temporal hauing supremacie ouer ecclesiastical person othervvise person ecclesiastical respect ecclesiastical function thing cause annexed proprelie belōging ecclesiastical make mee offer receiue parte othe shall able declare meanes maie svvere without committing plain manifeste periurie abilitie better apeareth none al mine abilitie herein shal appeare mine ansvvere abroad friendes declare constancie readines refuse othe wherebie thei might rather enduced continue good opinion conceiued also paie charge weekelie tovver sent vnto 26 26 vntruth quenes highnes vvordes tovver testifie contrary euerie saturdaie seruaunt wrote deliuered copy abroade tolde selfe nowe returned againe tower perceiuing friend gaue thē iust cause haue 27 27 heape slaunderous railing vntrute mistrust reuolte wauering inconstancie whereby estimation fame seruice god bellie decaied haue deuised set abroade selfe booke againe selfe ende altering chaunging nothing sauing haue geuen nevve name title seeme place though yee spake mee woordes l c vvhen deed neuer suche woorde spoken writen mee booke deliuered mee speache directed commissioner word vvhen ye quenes highnes cōmissioners shalbe able c fifth chapter priuate doings betwene fekenham horne yet one againe horne taketh hande fekenhās graūt may wel graūted ād great cūning skilfulnes wil thereof inferre may graunted nowe spitteth hande taketh faster holde thinketh seing lightnes former reason would geue greater weight newe fetch yet light weake employing manifest contradiction answered albeit man called ecclesiasticall person respecte churche cause function freely graunt horne yet neuer whit nearer purposehovve spirituall man vnderneath prince ād hovv vnlesse cā proue also respecte shoulde vnder prince cause ecclesiastical haue said subiect also laie men member beside ciuil common welth consideration whereof prince hath doe properlie spirituall man though bothe respectes cōcurrant one person named worthyer robert horne laie man painter queene properlye hathe dooe painter vnlesse lawe order concerninge painter robert horne highnes subiecte borne vnder obeisance queene haue also doe yea case yee true bishop winchester proprely bishop bishoply function whiche ye immediatlye vnder archebishop pope considering subiect otherwise bishop either touching temporalty farder true bishop also doe prince homage reason man haue saied hathe remoued prince superioritie concerninge mere bishoply priestly function notable contradiction hath full worshipfully cōcluded ſelfe eased fekenham also taking othe quene supreame head al cause temporal spiritual remayneth residew nothing greatlye answered shew horn doth accumulate huge heap vntruths notīg fekēhā impudent kind dealing writing whereunto presently required sweare may truely verefied seing horne self confesseth yt writē copy haue bene deliuered commissioner tyme haue presently tendred fekenham othe forme fasshion delyuered hornean heap • vntruthes vvherevvith fekenham falslie charged nothing altred later copy worde commissioner turned lorde bisshop winchester neither doth fekenham saye whereunto required presently sweare l saieth afterward l shalbe able c therefore maner impudency vntruthe matter euer yt matter nothing apperteyning state principal questiō smal importaunce nothing deseruing noted impudēt dealīg rather kind speach agreeth horn dealing folowīg speaketh fekenhā without regarde loosely lewdely saye maketh belly god frēds mistrusted reuolting wauering incōstācy sent foorth copy book horn termeth shedule sawe othe tendred lyke nowe false tale dewe circūstāces ye nedelessely required fekenhā necessarie haue bene obserued yow suerly rest true ye write seruante charge wekely defrayde frēds brought seruāte farre vnderstande stark false doe ye pray blinde fonde folishe false ghesses surmise make tale apparāte cowlorable clothing cōuenient dew circumstance ye much harpe vppon fekenham ye blindly lewdly harping vpō revolte slaunder deface ye say sent copy vnderstode right wel othe like tendered proue ye good sir catholiks made certain accompte end parliament othe haue ben offred thē cause exacted certainly know great plague immediatly reigned raged london pray god plague punish straunge procedings parliament holy church put v remembraunce greater plague imminēte hanging ouer v world onlesse repent special order goodnes mercy quenes maiesty tel well woteafter god plague horne beganne plage gramercy sir sore thirsted lōged catholiks bloud therfore sone god plague ceased thought haue self plaged catholiks exactīg othe doctour bonner bisshop lōdon lo began fellowes protestant bisshops wonderful plague scourge throwgh seking calling man othe matter meruelously fel ye felowes ye church bisshops whose authority ye forsaken defied also parliament bisshops vpō pitiful case state honour worship bisshoply authority yea faith al restethe dependeth meruelouse prouidence god ye could contente spoile true bisshops wordly estate honor must nedes haue poore lyfe al self founde bisshops statute realme lette thinges passe herken maister horne blaste 8 diuision pag 6 b fekenham first must booke othe vtterlye testifie queenes highnes onely supreme gouernour realme aswell spirituall ecclesiasticall thinges cause temporall testifie thinge vppon booke othe man may possiblye therein auoide periury except doe first know thing doth testifie whereof beareth witnesse geueth testimonye touching knowledge queenes maiesty onely supreme gouernour aswell spirituall ecclesiastical cause tēporal besides haue knowledge know way meane whereby shoulde haue knowledge thereof therefore part testifie vppon booke othe beinge without deede al knowledge cannot without committinge plaine manifest periury herein shal ioyne issue l whē l shalbe able either order gouernment sauiour christe left behinde gospel new testament either writing learned doctours olde new haue age age witnessed order ecclesiastical gouernmente christes churche either general councels wherein righte order ecclesiastical gouernement christes church hath beene faithfully declared shewed time time elles continual practise like ecclesiasticall gouernment one church part christendom vvhan lordshippe shal able fower meanes make proufe vnto emperour empresse king quene may claym take vpon thē gouernmēt spiritual ecclesiastical cause shal herein yelde humble thankes reken selfe well satisfied shal take vppon knowledge thereof ready testifie vppon booke othe horne reason argument moueth testifie vpon book othe q supremacy cause ecclesiastical man may testifie othe thing vvhereof ignorant knovveth nothīg vvithout committīg periury neither knovv q highnes onely supreme gouernour asvvel cause ecclesiasticall▪ temporall neither yet knovv vvay meane vvhereby haue knovvledge thereof therefore testifie vppon booke othe vvithout committing plaine manifest periury ansvveare minor seconde proposition argument although might plainly deny vvithout knovvledge vtterly ignoraunt matter vvay meane hovv come knovvledge therof put prouf vvherein knovv must needes faile yet vvil ansvveare plain negatiue thom aquin quaest 1 de malo distinctiō diuisiō ignorāce better excuse declare vvhat sort ignoraūt vvithout al knovvledge three kind ignorātes one simplicity vvilfulnes thirde malice first sort cānot haue longe time good oportunity much occasiō many vvaies vvhereby come knovvledge hereof yea haue knovvē profest openly deede vvorde vntruely yet hath somwhat orderlike proceeded followeth vntill come 20 leafe beside moste impudent shamelesse lyesm horn disorderly treatise wherwith would deface fekenham prosequuteth matter confusely vnorderly leaping tel howe whither verely thinke wit owne perchance encombred domestical affaire home could gather together lesse passed hodge potche made doings thinking like fellowes protestantes woulde take thing good gree knowing poore fekenham shut vp close inough al answering thinking catholique el woulde take vppon answere lewde booke thought horne olde testament ye woulde haue gone newe testament woulde haue laboured haue established matter therby belike world goeth hard behalfe ye doe sauing ye iumble testimonie two tell howe vnhandsomly purpose yea owne selfe wot well ye shall anon heare also meane worth labour well consider excellent pregnant witte greate skill man hath former treatise fekenham espied surely wisest best learned worlde trowe beside horne would neuer haue espied special grace man hath geuen maister deuill mere malice ioyned like follie fekenham heretike donatist yet fekenham somewhat beholding saith fekenham hath bewrayed secrete heresy wherein saith one part truely heresie matter surmised vppon certainly none secrete priuie argus himselfe al eye shall neuer espye horne selfe let prie neuer narrowly whereas side horn fellowes maisters luther caluins heresy secrete simple heresy manifolde open haue waye shift saue good name honestie blotted blemished euer without repentance obstinate maintenance many many hū dred yeares since condemned partly holy father partly general councels say fekenham hath secrete heresy donatus great grandsi • donatist catholikes auncetours truly shal vnderstād anon meane good syr may please fauourably heare maisters honorable pedegre worthy feares prowes haue heard perhapsm horn fellovves aūcetors mee suche thing may edifie catholike ād neuer answered heretike decies repetita placebunt bishop plaid chief parto vvhat craftie coper ād smothe ioyner horn gaue final though wrong wicked iudgemēt also shewed superiority though vngodly vpon man father would suffer interred prīcelike thē selues much worthy haue ben cast decease dog rauēs vpō dirty donghil honor haue ye gotte al crafty cooping cūning ād smoth ioyning al cō bining ād may say incorporating nūber nicephorus sentence together whiche yet one vide praefationem nicephor histo suam ecclesiasticā two leaues sunder first placed second second firste yet whole sentence neither piece patch sentence culled oute pretensed otheof constantine iudgemēt cause cecilian one point onely bisshop pope ciuil magistrate supreme iudge cause ecclesiastical yet yf horn could effectually proue quyte self lyke clerke dede maister caluin iewel others runneth example strong hold trow neuerthelesse wil proue anon stronge rotten rede artic 4 fol 105 sequent also indifferent reader may sufficiently appeare hath wil reade return vpon iewels lying reply whole matter answered ful yet let v one againe lay forth matter constantine say matter ecclesiastical deuolued appele appointed delegate pope selfe yea pope sentence appointed vppon new appeale certain bisshhops appellant also agreued sentence craued ayde constantitins hand gaue final sentence suerly froward quarreling men euer maner men horne forsothe ye truely say donatist peruerse obstinate heretiks euer churche suffred thinke sure grounde build supremacy vpon suerly sure sownd emperour emanuel ye call beside thism horne buildeth supremacy vpon doings donatist longe tediouse song ye songe late fekēham proue donastiste ye see donatist selues authority temporal prince churche matter ye denied may fekenhā clere donatiste ye done welm f purged horne selfe donatist yf ye eased reader self hādsome worde two interlaced auoiding contradiction wel belyke voluntarie obliuiō forslone wil therfore take paynes supplie defect say therfore true serued purpose lōg hope relefe wicked heresy ranne emperor yea iulian apostata setting forth smal cōmendations ayde helpe nowthe maruelous constācy donatist afterward constantin emperor made sharp lawes thē thē world chaunged sang new songe sitte seamely prince busie thēselues church matter yea impudent inconstant thowg • e themselues first browght matter cecilian emperours audience yet blame innocent cecilian fact breaker ecclesiasticall order maisters cōpanions beseache true schollers donatist behalfe haue shewed tell truth sentence geuen pope prouincial general councels yea emperours prince doth like prety shifte ye put proufes hadde thowght selfe would haue proued hī mere delegate seing speak perēptorely nothing extraordinarily see wel wil allwaies obiect brethern doe caring supremacy may proued athanasius hosiꝰ hilarius ād leōtius bisshops time praise god athanasius ad solitartam vitam agentes vbi literae hosij recitantur ad cō stantium hilarius lib contra constantium vvhat liking catholiks thē liuing yt vvhat hosius sayde supremacy vide suidam leontio vvhat leontius sayde supremacy men al notable lightes catholike church declared vsed authority withal declare great misliking thereof ād make • thē plain forerūner antichrist haue declared athanasius meddle sir emperour saith hosius mater church neither commaūd v thing rather learne handes god hath betakē cōmitted thée th empire ād v hath cōmitted church matter leontius b tripoli time constantius present synod bisshops busy talke set forth certain cōstitutiōs saith boldly vnto syr imaruail self ye leauing busy self mēs affaire commō welth warlik mater cōmitted charge charge forslow sitting amōg bi • hop ād • kīg lawes cōcernīg mater ecclesiastical wherin ye haue nothīg mā deposed bishop ye say haue ye foūd fair welfauored presidēt groūd primacy vpō wel fauored prēsidēt ād worthy folowed ye list see horn ye may learn nowel saw farder mater great deale prelatship hath laid forth lesse 13 article supreme gouernour horne proue busy gouernmēt dede antichrist thus iarre ādiūble againe one agaīst neuer agree tale called coūcel ariminū ād el induceth primacy haue shal better herafter declare namely whē com author cardnovvel fol 114 cusanꝰ meāsesō ye haue ministred good mater iustify pope primacy behold damasus broke ād disanulled al ariminū saith 32 meritò conciliū illud exhorreo good cause abhorre councell cause also day authoritie thus al horn exāples run roūdly hī ād quite ouerturne purpose possiblie false cause truly defended say liberius pope rome became arriā slaūderous vntruth brethrēs cōmō obiectiō ād hath oft bē soluted catholiks part bē bearīg self lerned prelate resume rusty reason replie catholiks answeres ād solutiōs ye able worste euer liberius make suspitiō banishmēt restored athanas ad solit vitā agēt tripart li 5 ca 17 yelded cōstātius athanasius saith expresly yelding arriā heresy hī become arriā volūtarily teache beleue allow arriā heresie thei al trow caluinists englād fear displeasure banishmente losse good practise order caluinists supper communion right catholiques matter ecclesiasticall sixth chapter valentinian emperour stapleton valentinian emperour commeth good time meane proue primacy horne quite ouerthrowe made expresse lawe ecclesiastical matter ecclesiasticall men iudge ambrose witnesseth expressely epistle wrote younge valentinian man sonne forme law causa fidei vel ecclesiastici alicutus ordinis eum iudicare debere ambr lib 5 epist 32 qui nec munere impar sit nec iure dissimilis haec enim verba rescripti sunt hoc est sacerdotes de sacerdotibus voluit iudicare cause faith ecclesiastical order iudge neither office vnequall neither right vnlike word rescript wil haue priestes iudge ouer priestes thus ambrose plainely expressely one sentence quyte ouerturneth al horne supremacy yea farre emperour al gouernment ouer priestes matter ecclesiastical euen matter ciuil temporal woulde suffer priestes called ciuil court thus foloweth immediatlye ambrose quinetiam si aliâs quoque argueretur episcopus morum esset examinanda causa ibidem etiam hanc voluit ad episcopale iudicium pertinere yea farder bisshop otherwise accused matter behauyour outwarde demeanor examined matter also would belong iudgement bisshops beholde gentle reader supreme gouernor al cause spiritual temporal ouer priest bisshops horne hath brought forth verily one ciuil cause refuseth gouernment ouer comm • unded ambrose consecrated bisshop millayn • saieth horne election prescribed bisshops graue oration qualified man bisshop ought c horne therefore supreme gouernour al cause ecclesiastical yea cause thinke supreme gouernour tolde v parte graue oration somewhat therein perhaps would haue appered either purpose graue oratiō made say graue talke wherein cōsisted tel v verily graue oratiō dede ād grauity thereof vtterly ouerbeareth light faith wel catholikes eunomians arians heretiks reading rented shedules sauing deliuered catholiks whereupon heretikes departed ashamed dashte countenauce whome ye also write examined faith sorte astonyed began fall amōges themselues lyking mislykīg emperours purpose ala good horne whie ye self nowe ye seame sodenly dasshed countenance yea whiche maruayle harde metall thinketh somwhat asshamed wonderfullye astonied withall man pluck vp harte good cowrage wil perchaunce say borde yowe sette vpon mery pynnes woulde god matter suche yt myght better lawghed pitied might serue democrytus one euer lawhed euer wepte thē heraclytus yet say truth cause muche bothe perchaunce nowe mā wil think doe ieste speake shame would god yt myght ons truelye sayde youe yt goodly sparcle grace growing wel put mēs iudgement ye dashed countenance yea ye wonderfully astonied horne lesse astonied telling storie ariās heretiks thē vvere vvhē thing vvas euen cause maner arians heretikes thē dare say proue yt arians asshamed dasshed countenaunce vpō doinges theodosius onely much yowe asshamed dasshed countenaunce whose heresy cōdemned many king catholyke emperours yf ye say ye asshamed must replie ô shamelesse fellowe impudente arians nowe adde ye astonied arrians heretikes facte theodosius therfore full slylie wylilye doinges emperour ye haue ouerhipped whyche yf ye put would haue serued aswel againste yowe yt againste therfore memorie yt astonied yowe ye durst shame name matter yet folly coulde ye forbeare patche yt speciall matter aduauncyng supreamacy first vvhy horne hath lefte principal matter ovvn storye tanquam cauis bibēs nil • hovv theodosius emperor dashed heretikes coūtenance socrat li 5 cap 10 heretiks fell diuisiō theodosiꝰ vvhe • vpon teareth sheduls faith vvhich offred theodosius allowe open disputation arians macedonian eunomians whiche verie redie yf bene lyuing late woulde ād euē cause disalowed allowed late westmynster disputation beinge mete leade common people truthe confirme truthe whereof haue alredie somwhat towched nowe praye yowe horn tel v emperours purpose heretyks lyked mislyked wherin yt dogge drinking nilus olde peruerbe feare stinging ye dare tary wel ye astonied memory yt wil tel emperor demaūded head secte whether allowe receyue father churche wrote diuision beganne yea marye say else reuerence honour maysters feare saieth story least yf sayde otherwyse people would wonderfully haue misliked theyre doings wel sayd sayeth emperour ye cōtente matter cōtrouersed stād saying testimonie beganne one stare vpon wiste nere world answere fynally fell owt self write amongs thē selues let emperor cal anabaptist zwinglians lutheran demaūde question woulde matter fall thinke yea hath yt alreadye eye priyng seking forth story theodosius opened shutte leaue iudgement indifferent reader dare firmely auouche thing whiche haue nowe last rehearsed beside willingly omitte drawe much nearer make pope seluesdist 79 si duo honorius constitute neither twaine shoulde pope newe election thirde shoulde chosen cōmon cōsente twoo saithe emperour lavve made humble sute bonifacius chaunce againste righte haue sought meane haue geuē self greate shameful fall beholde mighte laughe al skorne ye could haue foūd lightly el better occasion archadius emperour east honorius west excōmunicated pope themperour made law touching thelectiō pope pope desire belike great supremacy euē pope cōtent either geue hī suffer hand neither banishing pope frō rome especially schism horne specified causeth passe ouer next matter sauing horne commeth glosatour glosar cunninge sorte lawlike gloselike woulde hastely lepte ouer firste alleageth glosatour calleth assured meante proued common expositour canon lawe appeareth maister horne owne allegation bringeth glosar assured founde calleth glosatour haue extraordinary glose horne first authoriseda nevve glose canō law firste authorised horne perchance ye wil meruaile good reader especially ye exercised trauailed canon law horne shuld haue deape rare knowledge gloses canon law perchāce question might appose best doctor arch onles wer ackworth horn sōne law perchāce father speciall cōmision though perhaps horne neuer read glosar selfe hath authorised v new glosar thīketh eares itch heare glosar shuld ben wel horne haue eased reader doutful mater seing haue foūd lēgth shall al world shall know shall know horne much better therfore short carolus molineꝰ frenchman whose glose far yet learn scarse seuen yeres old therabout vide editionem iuris canonici 4 lugduni cum glos 1559 scarsely past infancy woulde hardly allowed speake onlesse horn bisshopped wherfore see cause may according manner score vp yet horne needes haue glosar perchaunce greatly sticke especially sence merely call glosar tongue vaine lyer thinke may truely call muche contende skape scoring vppe calling glosar surely shall meanes skape calling pope glosar commaūdement al bi • hop wheresoeuer faile appeare though emperour peremptorily cited summoned thē prince ciuile magistrate doe cite subiectes ciuil matter whereas history nicephorus alleaged geueth forth token peremptory commā dement rather contrary emperour letter whereby summoned niceph li 14 c 34 addeth reason threat would draw backe qui enim vocatus non alacriter accurrit non bonae conscientiae esse apparet whosoeuer called hasteneth verely appereth haue euill conscience woordes rather chargeth conscience god loyal obedience iosaphat priestes leuits olde law hath ben shewed2 paral 19 neither vseth threat force commaundement expresse much ynckling gloriouse supremacye horne would faine finde againe vide cyril epist 22 tom 4 ordering gouerning call councell ioannes come emperours lieutenaunte suche cyrillus al catholique bishoppes councell complained firste made true relatiō emperour councel done laboured haue iohn antioche confederate reduced communion holy councel hauing brokē canon request councell resisted plainlye saiyng possible force v hereto except haue done canon disanulled also become humble suppliauntes councell suche whiche haue offended iohn lieutenant could winne purpose way force authority whiche bishop acknowledged none matter synodicall concluded decreed went sleight compasse desired geue writing confession faith saied cause subscribe therevnto agree saieth councel might make vaunte say haue brought bisshops attonement conciliaui eos ad amicitiā humanis inter se offensis dissidentes nō exponimus no contumeliae variaunce among selues vpon worldly displeasure councell espiyng replied againe woulde geue world occasion reproche shame cō fession faithe required answered called hither heretikes come hither restore faith hath bene despised also restore emperour hath nede nowe lerne faith knoweth wel enough hath bene baptised thus see ordering gouerninge whiche horne cause dependeth vpon lieutenāt emperour mere tyrānical violēce godly emperours accustomed vse horne auoucheth constantine nicene coūcel theodosius man grandfather councell aquileia cyrill vbi suprà tyrannicall gouernment cyrillus whole synod writeth thereof thus greate vexation kept guardes souldiars yea hauing beddes side slepe specially saith cyrillus whole councell beside much weried vexed many dead many also hauing spent doe sell necessary lo honorable gouernement horne supreame headm horne groūdeth primacye vpon doeings iohn schismatical bisshop force armes extort cōsent gouernour would great turke souldan ruled againe suche rough paterns please verye well rough rude prelate simile habent labra lactuca wheras therfore calleth emperour theodosius verie godlie emperour seing calleth godly place respect action hereafter rehearsed lewd naught hathe shall yet better appeare plaine vntruth donec poenitētiā agatis et anathematisetis haeretica capitulum quae à cyrillo alexādrino episcopo exposita sunt cōtra euangelicam catholicam doctrinam liberatus cap 6 euer thinges therefore either shoulde haue forborne call least place shoulde haue founde better matter haue practised supremacie vpon al maister horne declaration resteth defended iohn bishoppe antiochia fewe confederate fautours nestorius councell condemned whoe made cyrillus residew ephesine father two hundred number heretiks called doings hereticall euidentlye appeareth selfe authour chapter horne taketh helpe ayde sweete vnsauery declaration wythall calleth thys ihon godlye man wandering circumstaunces leaueth owte thys least godlye reader might sone suspecte thys primacye standynge vppon better grounde yet horne saye theodosius practised supremacy first earle candidianus deputiethe cause vvhy horn taketh theodosius supreme head emperours behalfe inhibited cyril procede til comming iohn patriarche antiochia said iohn condemned cyril memnon deposed thē bishopriks emperour confirmed iohns sentence thirdly seing dissension betwixt cyril iohn grow cōmaunded agree otherwise would depose banish last iohn cited answere pope legate would come said looked prince answere said cause ansvveredbut thing neither seuerally iointly force first candidianus doings ye see goe externall moderation disposition order councels doings whiche haue saide one point emperours dealing councelles church best sonne supreme gouernour thereof secondarily emperoure deposed cyrill schismaticall assemble iohn cōsociates nū ber 34 liberatus writeth cap 6 contrary minde al residue whose sentence though wrongfully geuen theodosius sinistrally affected seduced doth confirme wherein principall worker executour sentence thirdly emperour threatned deposition depriuation banishment spirituall ciuile punishment impertinente matter therefore adde would depose thē ye glosar liberatus cap 8 good glosar pope brother molineus liberatus author hath word saieth threatened sende nicomedia banishment last al iohn beinge mā ād vpholdē emperour meruaile ye lefte author whō ye toke ād chapter perchaūce ye astonied heretiks theodosius euē place author sheweth coelestin presidēt coūcel deputy cyrill whō gaue instructiōs informatiōs letter agaīst hī cap satis euidenter distin 96 neither thēperor lieutenant thing either allowing disallowing ād wil proue vnto euē supreme head theodosius writīg cyrillus vt perturbatio quae ex cōtrouersiis istis accidit secūdū ecclesiasticos canones dissoluatur hurly burly thē cōtrouersies religiō might pacified quieted according ecclesiastical canōs ecclesiastical canō ending determinatiō matter spirituall apperteyneth clergy ād layty also answere take hādfast thing selfe haue alleaged wil ye know horne whether doings erle cādidianus thēperors deputy reached discussiō determinatiō matter ecclesiastical say saing cōfirmed appeale supreame head theodosius plead self cōmissiō gaue cādidianus deputatus est cādidianus magnificus come trā sire v que ad sanctissimā synodū vestrā ac nullo quidē quae facienda sunt de pij dogmatibus quaestiones communicare illicitum nam que est eū qui non sit ex ordine sanctissimorum episcoporum ecclesiasticis immiscere tractatibus haue sent saith themperour theodosius noble erle candidinianus deputye vnto holye synode geuinge charge medle anye poynte towchinge question moued abowte godlye doctryne religion yt vnlawfull whiche order holye bisshoppes entermedle ecclesiasticall matter yet ye saye iohn fellowes woulde appeare pope legate true man ye point dede wherein doinges good felowes protestante bisshops iohn refused come pope legate coū cel good right horne fellovves refused coū cel trent liberatus cap 6 horn supremacye destroyed ovvne author ā • chapter large saufe conducte called late councel trente durst ye knewe cause good shewe face ordinarie learned consistory ye knew ye able shewe good cause ye haue deposed catholike bisshoppes coulde iohn deposed cyrillus memnon therefore called geue reckoning doings pope celestins legate president themselues cyrill memnon put vp complaintes pope legats thē newly come rome cōstātinople whole coūcel bisshops durste appeare loe place ād chapter opē proufe pope ād ecclesiastical primacy withstāding euer emperour supreme head al allowing iohns wycked proceding pope legats councell supreme authority resumed matter hāds whō also cyrill memnon bisshops ephesus vniustly deposed offred billes cōplainte wherevpō iohn cited appere playd night owlespart able abyde cleare light pope authority ād honorable councel haue ye cōcerning ephesine councel spoken altogether saye ad ephesios poore ayde ye like take councels hand nay ye quyt ouerborē ād ouertilted therewith shall yet large appere vouchesafe reade haue writen synode ansvveare vnto heresy vvho vvoulde vvas heretik vvarrant vvoulde appeare bisshop fled prince liberat cap 11 appeare fledde vnto emperour theodosius declareth vnto griefe emperour sendeth vnto synod vvith eutiches one chiefe officer florentius vvith mandate bicause wee study carefully peace goddes churche catholike faith wil goddes grace haue righte faithe kepte whiche sette foorth nicene councell confirmed father ephesus nestorius cō demned wee wil therefore bee offence committed aboute aforenamed catholique faithe bicause wee knowe honourable florentius faithfull approoued man righte faith wee wil shalbe present synode bicause conference faithe vvas asistaunt vnto father 132 132 vntruth florētius vsed examination al examined eutyches openly synode 133 133 vntruth neuer asked hī one question diuerse time faithe finally saide vnto saithe florentius doth confesse christ twoo nature doth beleeue aright 134 134 vntruth florētius coū cel vvas cō demned deposed vvas eutyches excommunicate deposed condemned eutyches rested obteined emperour commaunde nevv synode constantinople vvherein examine actes former vvhether thinges touching proceding eutyches vvere orderly rightly appointeth besides florentius diuerse 135 135 vntruthe nicephorus hath thing noble councel see doings thereof vvhen eutyches coulde vvin purpose neither synodes procureth friēdship empresse eudoxia others emperour call synode againe ephesus vvhich synode emperour prescribeth fourme proceding synode vvas vvicked conuenticle vvherein truth vvas defaced heresie approued emperour seduced chrysaphius one priuy chamber fauour vvithe 10 chapter eutyches archeretike stapleton eutyches false monke ye flie frō ordinarie iudges suche iudges matter neither presence florētius emperours deputy councel maketh emperor haue sayd ād shewed supreame head much emperor sayth cōferēce sayth woulde deputy present graunted whē matter faith debated emperours dist 96 vbinam chal act 3 pa 838 cabil 6 milleuit cap 19 al christē mē hereof yt may inferred coūcels assembled disciplin ecclesiasticall faith thēperor deputy haue nothīg infrīgeth greatest part supremacy plain rule practise church expressed coūcels chalcedon cabylon milleuitum graunt emperours deputye may present councell matter faith debate present ende hath authoritye determyne decide controuersies haue alredy proued theodosius selfe stoppe belyke gappe ye imagin florentius play iudges parte examyne eutyches openly synod faith belieued examination florentius vsed none lay man beside might haue demaūded beleued demaunding determin ought belieue adde diuerse tymes faith vntruth florentius al synode neuer asked one question alleage synode hadde nowe condemned suppose ye would fasten iudges part vpon sayd eutyches doth confesse christe two nature doth belieue right might anie mā haue sayd symple sentence simple yt ye thought simply dubly craftely yea altogether falsly minding beare ignorant reader hād thoughe bene final sentence therfore ye say eutyches excommunicated deposed condemned pray maister horne florentius flauianus councell howe praye youe councell woordes florentius demaunde eutyches faithe liberatus cap 11 yea tell thou must confesse curse doctrine contrary faith nowe eutyches would said ye say many thinges would holy scripture hadde suche matter councel curse curse florentius spake woordes rehersed afterwarde cursed depriued priestly honour florenrius owne bisshop flauianus conteined chapter quoted yea playn place withal pope primacy flauianus sent sētēce rome eutyches thus cōdemned cōplayned letter vpon flauianus appealed pope leo eutyches rested pope primacy proued horn ovvn author chapter saieth horne dede eutyches haue paterne felowes wil ruled lawe authority metropolitane bisshop voyde none effect howe much knowen haue bene presumed see apostolike bisshop thereof present qui prae rogatiua beati apostoli petri per vniuersum orbē primatum obtinens sacerdotij statutis synodalibꝰ consueuit tribuere firmitatē bisshop prerogatiue blessed apostle peter hauing throughe whole worlde primacy priesthood hath bene wonte confirme decree councels presumed say layemen though certayn bisshops agreing vnto yet could preiudicat prelat knowen consecrated vndoubtedly voyde effect neither waye accompted amonge ecclesiastical decree thus farre synod selfe alleaged horne god rewarde geuing v good instruction selfe yf came frende let haue thankes therefore yf falleth willes yet god praysed sinne worketh somtime greater amēdement turneth horrible temptation confortable calmenesse storme came also vnhappy meaning hathe yet brought v happye information doctrine vtterly ouerthroweth heresye see horne laie magistrat yea king selfe yea though religiouse godly vtterly excluded authority cause ecclesiasticall whereby phantasticall primacie vanisheth cleane away also pope whome cal forraine power hath primacy chiefty supreame praeeminence priesthode onely rome romaine prouince saith synode self clerckly alleaged per vniuersum orbem throughout whole worlde parte worlde primate thus much saith synode thereby vtterly ouerthroweth whole effect othe partes whiche catholikes refuse swere vnto verely ye goe haue hitherto wil surely espied preuaricatour double faced proctour secreatlie instructing client aduersarie face protesting plead sentence vvith vvords vvherfore according king cōmaundement hath committed cause v refourme restore vnto symachus right euer ought haue within citie rome without stapleton hath horne fetch proue prince haue chief interest mater ecclesiastical deposition bishop yea pope selfe first angry mater boke councels mangled confusedly set foorth thorne pricketh disclose worlde saye truthe seeth owne conscience councellesm horne complaineth dareth shew vvhere thoro pricketh selfe councell alleageth dothe set foorth pope primacie grieuouse remembrance therof causeth speake tel verelye horne stepped foorth one fote turned eie vpon next leafe haue found clercklie worke made eunodius defence councell hand withall haue founde euident authority pope supremacie vppon state temporall spirituall also finde booke confirmed cc xxx bishop assembled rome synode leaue therfore horne complaint complaine tom 1 conc pa 1009 grieueth dede confusion confession ye find bishop concerning ecclesiasticall praeeminence liyng open thicke like great block way ye coulde passe ouer allegation haue patched must needes stumble breake shinnes therat grieueth ful sore let v see good holsome herbes ye cunning gardener haue gathered garden ye thinke lieth vnhāsomlie sluttishly ye say first councell called cōmaundement right honorable king theodoriche make honorable ye wil arrian shal ye make yf ye knew arrian martinus pol sabellicus honour might haue bene better bestowed el ye knewe reading small trow furnish boke yet say truthe small reading serue turne ye say called councell call forsoth cōsent pope symachus though coūcel called bisshops tolde king pope selfe ought call councels tom 1 conc pa 1007 col 1 singular priuilege due see rome see first merite ād principality peter ād authority coūcels singulorum ecclesijs tradidit potestatem gaue power ouer euery thing church kinge made aunsweare pope declared consente letter yea bishop satisfied king saiyng required sight pope letter king shewed vnto hād pope also self present licensed bishop examine matter litle affectu purgationis suae culmen humiliat desire purging hūbleth high authority dignity yet horne addeth synode presumed decree thing without king knowledge yf saied ought ye said somwhat presume may two thing farre sonder though yet one sense dede might ought haue proceded king consent without pope hath iudge world god neither cā iudged inferiours nec aliquid ad se praeter reuerentiā de ecclesiasticis negotijs pertinere pa 1007 col 2 bishop told king face finally king referreth whole mater synode plainly protesteth coūcels part prescribe ought done weighty mater mee saith king haue nothing doe ecclesiasticall mater honour reuerence cōmit heare heare matter ye shall thinke profitable christiās city rome might set peace point lo al horne supremacy driuen bishop proceding sentence doe declare pope symachus iudged man neither bound answere accuser committed god iudgemēt reason coūcel geueth appertaineth sheep pastour vnde secū dum principalia praecepta quae nostrae hoc tribuunt potestati ei quicquid ecclesiastici intra sacrā vrbem vel foris iuris est reformamus totamque causam dei iuditio reseruantes vniuersos hortamur c pa 1008 col 2 foresee prouide snare wolfe thē follow word reherse iudicial sentence declaration taken true bishop medle cause discusse iudicially would said canōs thei could therefore immediatly sentence ye haue hast brokē midle followeth doe reserue whole cause iudgemente god sette former parte recited parcell sayed sentence ye must needes doe haue ye sponne faire threade selfe prouing thing whiche thing yee fellowes denye pope iudged man haue ye nowe made supreame heade whole churche haue geauen selfe suche fowle fall worlde lawghe scorne see finde faulte councell mangled confusedlye sette foorth whiche plainelye pithelye confoundeth greate shame confusion euer yee haue broughte shall booke bringe againste pope primacye also well appeareth worlde nothing else pleaded vppon owne councell sentence mangled confusedly alleged fekenham might vpon good ground refuse othe ye cōpelled also take othe pope primacy squemish conscience yet refuse authority owne author text plainely auouched horne 62 diuision pag 36 shall manifestly proued testified oecumenicall generall councels vvherin order ecclesiasticall gouernment christes church hath ben catholike church sequentes igitur ea quae sacris definita sūt canonib cō 123 si ecclesiasticū negotiū sit nullam cō munionē habento ciuiles magistratus cū ea disceptatione sed religiosiss whiche hath receiued god common gouernment principality ouer men nowe thys place ye see serueth expresly church principality whose holy canon holy father themperour sayeth doth followe whiche wordes heauenly matter labour knowe make people faithfull verely ought bend power order men maners princely power represse insolency euill ought geue ayde encrease peace quiet muche ought study desire thinke cō sidered haue tolde yowe stuffed authority concernyng pope primacy yelde truth 46 yeares forsake abandon greate schisme false heresie doth dasel amase yowe heare patriarche constantinople confesse whole councel yf name pope vitalianus receyued againe theyre dypticha raced sondred ād sequestred selues catholike churche woulde forthwithe returne thyther againe whereunto emperour councell by▪ agreed therevppon councell made manie gratulatorie exclamation anie way stay redresse thys huge schisme englande else euen put churche bokes pope name imbrace againe hys authoritie doe ye take yt hart horne see pleadinge macarius heretyke also iewells ordinarie fasshion pleadinge vppon doings heretical bisshops emperours grounding hym self vpon nomber patriarch constantinople antioche diuers vnhappie macarius property heretyke nyppe breake mangle mayme father testimony therevppon oft taken maner nowe cōfessing forthwith depriued bishoply attierment plucked backe would god yt might please quenes maiesty honorable coūcel play supreame head good emperour cōstantinus iudges make indifferēt search vewe whether catholiks late boks iewel horn ād fellowes play macariās thervppō euē horn sayd thēperour cōstantine geue iust iudgmēt sentence redie sownde way quailing ād appeasing huge scisme without book wil excessyuely growe eche part rather encrease cōtentiō thē ful pacificatiō part fault fownd dowbte nothing yt wil cōfessed therevppon theyr part harty renūciatiō al schisme heresie would wishe theire rich plucked shuld remaine good worldly estate al hurt wish thē nowe horn returne matter ye see poore iudgmēt poore selie supremacy ye geue emperour ād noble wherin effect whil ye would seme aduāce exalt thē ye make theyr office much better thē register notary office office though honest worshipful perchaūce yet dowbte whether honorable many yeares past one fellowes protestāt prelats sayd one thowed register tel thee regesters office honorable cōstantines supremacy antiochians sewed themperour appoint archbisshop place macarius appointment archbisshop imployeth supremacy diuerse king england haue appointed bisshops archebisshops realm yet none euer toke vpon either name authority supreme gouernour al cause ecclesiastical vntil miserable tyme heretikes authority prince establishe heresy haue spoiled god minister church dewe authority gouernement haue told horne cōstantin hath disclaimed supremacy supreame iudgement cause ecclesiastical wherof also next matter immediatlye rehersed thing alleage good sufficient proufe wil therfore onely self hys successours also ye make pope onely erre selues also confirme theire bretherne remoue errour answere case pope open lawe decree made consent brethern synod consistory promulged obserued throwghe christendomme set forth heresy reply good effectuall suche decree ye haue shewed euer shall shewe making suche lawe blessed hande god doth vpholde euer hath vpholden pope promise sake promise fared also letter pope adrianus sent thēperour patriarche constātinople towching reuerēd image beinge proponed ād reade father vniformely ioyfullie cōdescēde cōtentes thē ful testimony therof act 2 eche one set hys hād ād subscriptiō sayd adriā writeth tarasius patriarche cōstā tinople ōlesse wel knowen tarasius good syncere zeale ād catholike fayth touching image ād sixe general pope apostle vvhose greate champion vvere euen suche ecclesiasticall matter apostle treateth hath apostle epistle pope asketh holines fatte bakon eaten pope answereth wel smoke dried resty soddē likewise asketh whether shall eate dawes crowes hare wilde horse pope biddeth beware wise also asketh howe horse haue falling sicknesse shall doe pope aunswereth hurle ditche asketh shall doe beastes bitten madde dogge pope biddeth kepe close hurle pitte asketh one nonne may washe others feete men may pope answereth yea goddes name also asketh howe many cross aboutes 300 300 vntruth questiō vvas
