pleade vpon zacharias epistle bonifacius proue charlemains supremacye wherein pope primacy euidently openly declared haue shewed yf ye ignorant impudent maliciouse person yf ye wittinglye willingly alleage strong councel ye grounde selfe vpon de synodo autem congregata apud francorum prouinciam mediantibus pipino carolomano excellentissimis filiis nostris iuxta syllabarum nostrarum commonitionem per agēte vice nosiras tua santitate qualiter egistis cognouimus omnipotenti deo nostro gratias egimus qui eorum corda cō firmauit vt hoc pio opere adiutores existerent et omnia optimè et canonicè peregisti tam de falsis episcopis et fornicarijs et schismaticis quamque etiā et c called dede pipyn caroloman according pope geuen commission letter bonifacius pope legate concealing wherof left qui est missus petri pope legat prince ayders assisters vnto boniface proceding well canonically deposed false adulterouse schismaticall priestes yrketh horne heart remēbring selfe wel canonically handeled beare muche lower saile beare either bisshoplye priestly office faring like mad mā speaketh wot nere euen egle eies findeth fault men blindnes sheweth self blind bussard al may wel find fault moses law supreme authority new papacy may laugh scorne moses wel bonifacius cal hī blind bussard also madd lawes forbidding eating camel hare swine egle goshauke crow rauen owle carmorāt zacha ad bonifac tom 2 concil fol 450 col 2 like might also well make selfe pastime ieste merely canon sixth general councel lately spake forbidding eating pudding thing suffocated vvhy horne outragius agaīst bonifacius leuit 11 perchaūce questiō beast bitten madde dogges hath matter horne doth yet withal philosophy cōsidermē waxē mad eating svvines flessh bittē vvith madde dogge lycosthen de prodigijs anno 1535 vvirtenbergēsi ducatu c good brother germanye haue late considered fealing smart ignorance feading vpon swine flessh bitten madde dogge waxed madde dog falling one vpon pitifully bitte tore one others flessh questiō cōcerning nūne horne hath great cause mislike nowe case bonifacius demaunded pope zacharie whether lewde lecherouse false fryer might lurke luske bedde nunne cloke incest vnder name holy wedlock ād pope zacharie geuen honourable answere late apostle frier luther hath donne aswel hys bokesas hys damnable doings lo bonifacius ben true sincere apostle iesus christe haue ben horne idole tom 2 cōcil fol 452 col 2 nā et hoc flagitasti à nobis sanctissime frater sacri canonis praedicatione quot locis crux fieri debeant fol 453 col 2 c neither bonifacius demād matter ignorante anye greate doubte worke suerly pope hys answere telleth hym well sene holy scripture question many cross mā make body bonifacius question question cross made saying holy canō masse name holy canon ye abyde deuill signe holie crosse whome ye haue learned thus mangle allegatiōs caste away crossing canō wythal horne 96 diuision pag 58 adrianus first pope muche vexed ovvne 304the 304 vntruth slaunderous furious pride desiderius king lombardy sendeth carolus magnus requireth ayde lombardes promising make 305the 305 vntruth appereth history dist 634 therfore emperour rome charles cōmeth vāquisheth desiderius passeth rome vvhō pope receiued vvith great honour geuing part recompence title christian king augment beneuolence tovvardes charles desired sende bishop fraunce celebrate synode rome vvhere vvere gathered together bishop abbottes prelate 154 vvhich coūcel also carolus selfe vvas present saith martinus gratianus maketh report hereof churche history vvise charles vanquished desiderius came rome ād appointed synode holdē adrian pope adrian vvhole synode deliuered vnto charles right povver elect pope dispose apostolique sea graunted also vnto dignity aunciēt bloud rome vverby vvas made patriciā capable emperial dignity furthermore decreed tharchbishops ād bishop euery prouīce shuld receiue inuestiture none shuld cōsecrate onles cōmēded ād inuestured bishop kinge vvo euer woulde doo contrary decree accursed except repēted goodes also cōfiscate platina addeth charles pope romaine ād frēche sweare one keepe perpetuall amity shuld enemy thē anoyed one 10 chapter charlemayne adrian leo bishop rome stapleton adriā vexed king desiderius throwgh hys owne furiouse pryde magnitudine animi consilio doctrina et sanctitate vitae cū quouis optimo pontifice comporari potest vertuouse learned man nothing follishe furiouse lying also promised charles make hym emperour would ayde helpe hym history saieth except horne pēne history doth furder cause thys charles righte power electe pope inuesturing bishop seeing helde yt hys owne right tytle speciall gratiouse graunte pope hys synod self alleage nay verely one exāple cleerly destroyeth al imagined supremacy al shall bringe hereafter emperours claime electiō ād inuesturing bishop diligēt reader remē brīg first original ād authority hereof sprong imperial right power pope special graunte made charlemayn first emperour west trāslatiō therof must also see al bring hereafter themperors claime behalfe proueth primacy prince rather self confesse good reader take hede horne would stilie make beleue charles councell bishop forbid landes goodes geuen church man soules helth praied deathe whiche deede councell forbiddeth men shal entised perswaded enter relligion geue good churche onely vppon couetousnes animarum etenim solatium inquirere sacerdos non lucra terrena debet quoniam fideles ad re suas dandas non sunt cogēdi nec circumueniendi oblatio namque spontanea esse debet iuxta illud quod ait scriptura voluntariè sacrificabo tibi priest saieth councell shoulde seke helth sowles worldly gaines christian either forced craftely circunuented geue away theyr good owght willing offering accordīg yt writē wil willingly offer sacrifice thee next canon yt sayde hoc verò quod quisque deo iustè rationabiliter de rebus suis offert ecclesia tenere debet euer man hath offred vnto god iustly reasonably 39 muste church kepe styl prayer dead ther special canon made coū cell euery masse shoulde prayer made suche departed hath hys owne story auaunced pope also alleaging roman councell tyme pope sīmachus may iudged mā clergie people rome make answere charles hym self mā cā iudge pope writeth horne owte platina sabellicus ād writer lykenes ād agreablenes writing thē howe horne primacy become trust length ye wil discharge fekē ham frō othe say yow owne volūtarie allegation man forced yow vnto mightie truth bewraying false cause greate folly yet leaste sayde folly preuarication shoulde open saye somwhat yt maye seame worke thowghe miraculously yet wō derfully euer thys leo tong cut roote mē write could speake neuerthelesse ād though fowle lying mouthe pope primacy stopped true declaratiō yet wil speake hys owne honour leo hys vtter cōfusion ād shame forsoth sayeth horne charles toke thys answere lesse insufficient greauous wel sayde tyme horne sauinge yt moste vntrue ād ye lay forthe prouf shal ye neuer able proue yt yet ye coulde proue yt ye shoulde dooe none thinge whiche yee doe omnes diligeret neminem odio haberet tardus ad iram promptus ad misericordiam defacing ād dishonorīg clergie worthy ād self cal noble prīce charles withal would fayne procede next matter vntruthes must go also discouered yow say without prouf yea good prouf layd cōtrary pope leo streight dealing hateful romās author sabellicus platina say quite contrary platina among manifold notable vertues telleth man myld nature loued men hated man slowe wrathe ready take mercie pitie sabellicus matter sayeth thus coniuratorum odium pontificem inde ortum ferunt sabel aenead 8 〈◊〉 8 quòd illi liberius viuere assueti ferre nequiuissent grauem pontificis censuram saied hatred cō spired spronge hereof accustomed liue licentiously coulde abyde graue rebuke censure pope nowe horne able denie aswell carolus gaue ouer iudgmēt wold could geue agaīst leo falleth quarellīg leo owght haue cōmēded matter standing thus mā stepping forth lawfully proue thing agaīst leo rhegino chronic cum nullus probator aut testis legitimus appateret good man thowghe man coulde force yt yet knowing owne innocency toke open othe vppon holy ghospel gyltlesse suche matter obiected horne beinge pleasantly people yea owne selues preache profitable honest true thinges doe leade vnto eternal life enstructe others also doe firste euery preacher must preache general thei beleeue father sonne holy ghost himselfe hath forvvarned apostle paule timothe doth vvitnesse therefore beloued let v furnishe selues harte minde knowledge truth may able vvithstande aduersaries trueth thorough goddes grace goddes pope iohan neuer pope iohan could nexte rather fable storie al great busines apologie others make therein confut apolog fol 164 thinke hath ben already sufficiently proued neither nede make much wondering matter except ye list wonder selues whiche doe place pope supreme authoritie prince men woman yea chyldren fewe yeares haue three man childe woman lesse meruaile bene many hundred yeres one woman pope yet sayed vtterly false hath bene sufficiently proued touching confirmation pope inuesturing bishop adrian leo graunted charles greate whych ludouicus hys sonne gaue ouer againe prince coueted haue owne handes againe denied gratian hath collected example sydes geueth forth true euident reason well one first graunted also afterwarde iustly denied fyrst sayeth dist 63 electiōs pope entēt authority strengthened heretike schismatike dare gainsaie also end prince selues deuout childrē shuld agree vpon sawe chosen father thing might aide assist example valentinian themperour ambrose saith emperour wil thy aide defence becometh degree herevpon pope steuen horne talked euen made decree without emperours legate present bishop alreadie chosen consecrated reason decree bishop obstinat full word purpose sayed omnes nouimus quòd laici estis non adduximus vos latrare sine ordine facere verba knowe laye men brought hither barke talke order emperour saieth cusanus called therefore laye men ordered photius selfe bisshop felowes horne bishop mere laye person ordered none selfe ordered whereas one photians eulapius name beganne talke emperour legate see apostolike sayed eulapius condemned excommunicated see apostolike therefore emperour ought talke emperour sayed haue oftentimes much desired might perish therefore called hither returne church whatsoeuer patriarch shall iudge shall nill stande vnto man reiecte power geuen meaneth high bisshops christ god sauiour thus agayne see maister horne howe iudgement resteth bishop iubet imperator vt loquamini sed videntes iudices conuicia vestra nec audire vos volunt howe sentence see apostolike preuayleth howe buxomely vse owne worde obediently emperour yeldeth thereunto intermedling farder procure partes may heard tumulte may auoided iudges bisshops called actiō may quietly procede sētence last al sētence may put executiō notwithstanding indurat malice obstinat heretikes 8 action al schismatical longe notable oration synod cusanus lib 3 c 23 expressing dewe zeale dewty emperour al synodes councels auoucheth plainly secular laye men non est datum secundùm canonem dicendi quicquam penitus de ecclesiasticis causis opus enim hoc pontificum sacerdotum est graunted rule churche speake thinge al councel ecclesiasticall matter worke saith bishop priestes commē ding bishop greate paynes trauaile councell speaketh laye nobylyte present thus de vobis autem laicis c touching lay sorte wel beare office priuate men haue say vnto lawfull meanes moue talke ecclesiasticall matter neither resiste point integrity churche gaynesaie vniuersal synode searche seke matter belongeth bisshops priest beare office gouernours haue power sanctifie binde loose haue obtayned keyes churche heauen belongeth v ought fedde haue nede sanctified boūde loosed bande whatsoeuer religion wisedome laye man yea though indewed internal vertues longe lay man shal cease called shepe againe bisshop howesoeuer vnreuerent naked vertue longe bishop preacheth dewlye woorde truthe suffereth losse pastorall vocation dignitye haue doe standinge yet roome shepe shepheardes haue power discusse subtiltye woordes seke compasse thinges aboue v must therefore feare sincere faith harken vnto reuerence countenance ministres almightye god bearinge fourme seke belongeth degree vocation thus farre emperour sab meaneth thīg meaning although vvere kinges emperours yea • execute princely office authoritie ouerseing correcting reforminge churche matter mynisters therefore state vvas miserable confusion vvere thinges especially church rome till god stirred vp vvyse mighty prince otho first vvhose zeale stoutnes trauayle reforming religion disordred churche tongue able expresse saith nauclerus stapleton make sabellicus saie great deale thē euer saied intended say doth certaynely ascribe cause pretend saieth nō immeritò quis suspicaretur mā may ād without cause suspecte horne pope kept euill rule geuen al lewdenesse bicause emperours ouersee woulde haue folke think sabell aenead 9 lib 1 therefore make sabellicus conclude calamyte fraunce italy churche rome quòd ea gēte desitum esset imperari bicause kīg emperour beare rule false translation maketh proufe knowe horne ea gente doth signifie english may finde faulte grammer slacked honesty farre leaue english thereof quyte pad strawe sabellicus saieth cause calamyte bicause kinge emperour beare rule ea gente stocke line charles great whose posterity hitherto lineally reigned downe arnulphus last mentioned emperour last dede opinion historian charles lineal descēt dede churche great trouble disorder space 50 60 yeres howe euil pope cause disorder woulde horne folowing herein steppe baudy bale thinke haue noted compasse 50 yeres diuers good vertuous pope ruling churche twenty 50 yeres cause al disorder euil life certaine pope much licentious lewdenesse italian especially roman tyme dede lacke iustice emperours partes thinge sabellicus cō plaineth liued enormously licētiously makīg king amonge themselues oppressing one also moste vily cruelly handlinge bisshoppes good vertuous whome stephen 8 pope much holynes tyme naucler generat 32 pa 85 martinus pol cytyzens shamefully mangled disfigured fayne long tyme shame kepe within dores liued three yeres greate vexation trouble cause al trouble churche tyme yf liste shortly knowe gentle reader sabellicus agreing herein historian wil clerely tell saieth quantū francorum pietate c looke howe muche rome italy breathed alonge continuāce misery aenead • lib 1 godlynes bountifulnes frenche prince charles issewe one whole age almost 100 yeares much fell backe againe kinde calamytie space almost 60 yeres ciuil sedition calamyty beganne last yere adrian 3 ended time iohn 12 see whereof sprange calamytie horn imagineth bicause prince practise ecclesiastical gouernement ouer pope sabellicus better historian horne addeth immediatly vpon former wordes causeex qua iniuria videtur mihi orta tāta rerū mutatio quantum humanis rebus facta est enimuero praeter normannos c verely beside norman wasted fraunce outrage great chaunge thinges made worlde semeth haue sprounge hunnes also people scythia bolde vpon trouble fraunce coming downe slauony conquer landes gepides auari people quarter called ouerrūning thē forrain nation ciuill sedition italy caused greate calamyty historyans time complaine muche whych encreased emperours time arnulphus conradus henrie first yea otho hym selfe vntyll later ende hys empire partly would partly could represse tyrantes italie whych hurley burleys tā corruptis moribus nauclerus generat 32 vbique esai 24 whych breach good order licentiousnes lyfe corruption worlde head also selues chiefe bishoppes sometimes fell disorder lewdenesse life yt lesse maruayled wyll consider course god prouidence thys worlde suffreth sinnes people vt sicut populus sic sit sacerdos lyke people also priest saieth also lyke enormity worlde osc 4 dabo pueros principe eorum esaiae 3 et effaeminati dominabuntur eis 2 reg 24 geue child prince meaning onely child age child wisedome child strength child vertue also expressely reade wrath god wexed hotte israëll stirred vppe dauid say ioab goe number israël iuda great vanitie ouersight king plague fell vppon people vpon king god plagueth wickednesse subiects citation vvith maxime principle romanum pontificem à nemine iudicari debere pope ought iudged anye man vvhen legate emperour came octauian straight vvaies obeyed brought papia 404 404 vntruth omitting next sentēce vvherein pope primacie ouer emperour manifestlie declared vspurg saith rouland vvas oftentimes monisshed come contemne monition emperour faite councel radeuicus frifingēsis vvho vvrote actes vvitnesseth • ad made oration vnto bishoppes vvherein declareth example auncestours constantinus theodosius iustinianus later time carolus magnus povver authority call councelles vvhere churche trou • led vvith schismes perillous distourbance belongeth emperour notvvithstanding cō mitted desining cōtrouersie theyr vvisedome 405 405 vntruth none geue behalfe gaue therevnto authoritie councell debateth cause consulteth vvith men learned lavve concludeth octauians election vvas good adiudgeth righte bishoppe rome vvhē thus tryed matter fredericus emperour saith platina confirmat sente octauianus nevv confirmed pope tovvardes rome vvho dyed iourney vvhose death emperour called councell vvirtzberge auentinus vvriteth vvherein vvere great number archebishoppes bishoppes ād also many noble state empyre councell statute decree vvas made common consente hence foorth none shoulde pope onelesse created consent emperour accordinge custome bene longe auncient time vvorthy emperour vvhom chronicle call christianissimum moste christian zeale tovvardes goddes churche endeuored vvithout great perill selfe estate reteine iurisdiction due prince thereby refourme horrible disorder mater nostra rom c reioyce mother rome bycause seluses hidden treasure earthe opened riuers ād heapes mony maye flowe vnto thee great abundance glad iniquitie sonnes mē bicause mony geuen thee recompence great euilles mery iocund discordes sake thy helper bicause rushte infernall pit plentiful rewardes money might heaped vpon thou hast thou hast alwaies thyrsted synge pleasant balades throughe mennes malitiousnesse thy godlinesse thou hast ouercome worlde 18 chapter frederike barbarossa alexander 3 stapleton maister horne good reader hath hitherto doth styll playe cacus parte liuius lib 1 dec 1 cacus stole hercules ox woulde haue espied track drewe thē caue tayles backward whiche thing hercules seing nothing mistrust shoulde therem horne playeth cacus parte stole hercules ox yet passed droue beastes beast denne lackinge theyr company beganne maner bellowe wherby thefte discried boke horne denne cacus pretye sleight conueyeth hys story proufes man maye say taile backewarde keeping righte customable waie order making true faithfull allegation craftelie peruersely cutting chopping away parte partely lying cacus denne bellowing companie bewrayeth horne slie dealing haue ye hitherto found shall ye still good reader finde loe haue hande ready proufe frederike saith horne seing horrible vice romis • h church commaund • legate church rome come germanie c octauianū pontificem cōfirmat eumque albo equo sidentē per vrbē ticinensem ducit de mo • e adorat platina alex 3 tunc episc ad pes octauiani prosternūt imperator quoque id ipsum fecit vt ab eo indulgentiā acciperent sibi obedientiam sacerent vspurg quem imperator concilio papā declaratū adorauit equū eius de per vrbem deduxit whereas manner al runne one way wherof assured al horne owne primacie part testimony cut eche caried craftely horn cacus caue bewraieth al horn theft wil ye proue like regiment horne frederike doings ye maintaine goe see ye proue v substantiallye refused ye say pope rouland yet receiued pope octauian confirmed ye say yea ledde citie pauia sitting vppon white horse adored platina nauclerus saye vspurgensis saieth fell flatte feete receiue pardon become obediensarie al ye saye therefore heare hercules stolen ox bellowe cacus denne maister horne eares paciently abide al octauian ye write mā pointes honest relligious thing perceiue made saint death naucler geuer 39 said many miracle done tombe luca buried image nicodemus stomake disgest maister horn suffer supreme head like slaue kisse pope feete become maister horse ye suffer miracle pope tombe yet notwithstanding shall man point honest religiouse chance haue least cō fort one pretie nip ād tel v called hī self victor entēded victorious cōquerer deede vppon supreame head emperour frederike surely maruaile ye shoulde fauourably encline false antipope rather true pope dede rouland platina writeth elected 22 cardinal octauian 3 onlye therfore frederik mainteined hī rouland occasion horrible schisme ye speak rouland euer ād takē true pope yea taken length frederike also cō ming venice kissing holy feete seeing ye haue made pope hand holyesupra 114 diuision bolde make yea feete victora fable apology foxe touching thys alexander treading thēperours necke alexander yet roreth owte apologie hym put yll fauoredly mōstruouslie emperours neck vnder feete whiche semeth 40 whiche thowghe catholyke yet muche inclinable german cōmōly emperours parte semeth rather lyke narration blondus thēperour thē vsual honor kyssing pope foot tale thapology true fox doth also ioly gay picture set forth thowgh yt make commendation pope moderation humility yet yt maketh hys supreame authority obey sayeth emperour thee peter whome thow doest succede thentent horne apologie oppressiō almayne army spoyling ād wasting al aboute rome naucler gener 39 pag 225 emanuel emperour east sent embassadours promysing bothe great hoste almayne emperour friderike also vniō grecian romain church would suffer romain empire lōge diuided frō time charlemayn come agayne one heade empire whome also banishment sayde emperour sent seconde embassy great quantytie mony promysing reduce whole east churche vnder subiection west grece vnder rome woulde restore emperour constantinople crowne west empire frederike seemed nowe rightlye worthely depriued pope notwithstanding greate misery stode presentlye daily like suffer power frederike answered se nolle id vnum coniungere pag 226 quod olim de industria maiores sui disiunxissent woulde ioyne one forefather olde time purpose diuided trowe denie horne circumstance duely cōsidered great ād rare moderatiō pope alexāder 3 worthy set forth figure ād picture posteryty sober vertuous facte whiche mayster fox hath blased oute prowde hasty except charyties suche verely semeth take delight vice vertue rather heare one lewde fact pope twenty good charyte charyte paule describeth thinketh euill 1 cor 13 protestant lacke true charyty reioyseth vpon iniquyte reioyseth verytie suffreth thinges beleueth thinges hopeth al thinges beareth thinges contraryewyse thinke reporte alwaies worst reioyse take greate pleasure vpon iniquytie ought men reuerence sorye haue veryty truthe tolde suffer beare nothing church euil life fewe forsake cōmunion societie whole beleue much pleaseth hope accordingly thus muche way one touching greate ambition desire speake euil pope reporte worste doe booke horne haue done plentifullye exactlye throughe whole processe nō vt iudicaret eos aut causam sedis apostolicae sed vt à prudentibus viris maner spiritual iurisdiction exercised practised hym yt behoued protestant especiallie horne thys boke euer proufes country yet conuenient prouf olde practise concerning newe primacie englande haue wrowght matter substancially least wise owne countre shulde haue browght forth good aū cient autentique matter wil ye nowe see wise euen dealinge protestant prelats pynne vp proufes wythin vj hundred yeares christm horn firste thousand yeares shevveth example primacie practised britannie fol 93 col 2 euer bring theyr iewell telleth v ful merelie come late horne matter supreamacie weightie poore catholiks deniyng thereof greauously punished lawes anie matter nowe lying controuersie betwene catholyks protestantes englande horne say thys owne country approued chronicler reporte self alleageth first al romā prouinces publiquely embrace christes relligion one thousand yeares standeth mute belike thinking william conquerour conquered aswell olde catholyke fayth englande lande people fansieth duble conqueste one vppon good body vppon sowles faythe englishe men shall nowe say noble worthie champion shall dryue hym litle backem horn begīneth newe primacie vvith vvilliam conquerour thovv • h cōquered lande fayth vvithall iewels peremptory challenge tel commeth late almoste fyue hundred yeares shall deale freely liberally iewell doth whith v bydde hym take beste helpe hym self verely horne nede yet lytle purpose aswell conquest hath sufficient prouf pretensed supremacy prouf euer bringeth yt must yelde geue place first thousand yeares whiche beare ful testimonie pope primacie king luciꝰ ād realme christened bi • pope legate • ireneus li 3 ca 3 ad hāc enim propter potentiorē principalitatē necesse est oēm cōuenire ecclesiam hoc est eos qui sunt vndique fideles qua semper ab hijs qui sūt vndi que cō seruata est ea quae est ab apostolis traditio beda li cap 13 • rosper chronic doe day kepe preserue fresh immortall sent england sayed eleutherius godly wonderfully worke thys great conqueste nowe aske horne lucius meant send farre instructours teacher christian fayth namely fraunce beyng hande thys tyme christian church adorned wyth many learned bishoppes martyr though woulde perchaunce seeke manie pretye shyfte shyfte awaye thys demaunde yet neuer make good sufficiente aunsweare vntyll confessed pope primacye verie cause send farre blessed martyr god great learned bishoppe lyon fraunce ireneus writyng tyme firste apostle eleutherius doth confesse writyng church muste agree wyth churche rome sayed churche hath greater principalitie tradition apostle haue euer bene kept case nowe pope nothing doe matter ecclesiasticall within ileland tyme olde britaines pope celestinus appoint scottes theyr firste bishop palladius prosper writeth notable chronicler age dyd also send thys ileland germaine bishoppe antisiodorum bryng apostolicall authoritie britaynes heresye pelagians sayed prosper witnesseth lett v nowe come tyme saxon conuerted augustine shall fynd manie full testimony pope primacie prince subiection trowe horne selfepope celestinus practised supremacye saxōs tyme impudent denie ouerpasse reason readely foūd confirme toke sonne adoption also annoynte consecrate king englande manifolde practise said primacy continued king tyme euen tyme tyme blessed edward immediate predecessour william sauing harolde reigned one full yeare twenty yeare said king edwarde blessed man wulstanus monk prior consecrated bisshop worceter man suche notable vertue austerity lyfe resembled olde vertuouse renowned religiouse men one among notable quality continued praying studiyng fasting somtymes foure dayes foure night neuer slepte litle reste toke vpon foorme churche vsing none bolsterre booke wherin prayed studied man saye made bisshop confirmed pope legats realm cōquestehe vvas cōfirmed pope legats cōquest henry hūtingto authour doth write vncertain heresay certain knowledge mā age one semeth sene blessed man ād talked discourse vpon particularity vpon continual appeale rome vpon willes charteres writing sent rome auoide tediousnes doe purposely forbeare nowe notifie good reader two thīgs first tyme good kinge offa yere lord 760 gaue example inas long idem hēr hunting polid l 4 continual practise pope primacy realme england conqueste payinge peter penny ād receiuing palle pope vicare peter peter penny euen cōquest payment said peter penny hath continued frō tyme tyme leuied king taking good diligent order sure paymente secondly tyme augustine first archebisshop among saxon al archebishops euen conquest receaued palle rome infallible token subiectiō pope peter successour vpon whose holy tombe palle first layed ād taken sente archebisshop two token subiection cōtinued frō tyme time conqueste continewed also without interruption onlesse verie seldome litle space reason priuate controuersie betwixte pope kinge euen thence freshe memorie beside many notable thing otherwise realme since conquest continually practised serue declaration confirmation said primacy perchaunce horne wil say sir though specifie nothing conquest iustifie prince supremacy yet margent booke doe remitte reader booke made king henry 8 day de potestate regia wherein may see doinges king england realme conquest matter ecclesiastical prety clerklie remission dede sende reader one thowsande yeares together ye shoulde haue laide hī best principal proufs seke book wotteth whē lēgth foūd shal proue matter substātially ye haue done hitherto selfe therefore ye worke signes profers marginal note wil remitte reader 411 vntruth much one example nevve primacye brought foorth boke cōcerning englād therfore marginal lie horne ye novv vvelcome englande horne vvithall ioly companye vvith 400 vntruthes cleauing faste syde beside many trym follie othervvise marginal note also ful aunswere nowe lette v goe forwarde god name see whether kinge william conquered bothe lande catholike faithe one lette v consider yf kinge realme acknowledge pope supremacy much reuerently christian prince doth liuīg say nothing othe toke day coronation promising othe aldrede archbisshop yorke crouned hī peter alter westminster clergy people would defende holye church gouernours tel reader good horn beseche king williā contrary aunciēt order vsed euer since crowned stigandus thē liuing archbishop canterbury vv conquerours othe addit ad noueoburg m promittēs se velle sanctas dei ecclesias ac rectores defendere bishop york yf ye wil shame betraie cause tel reader wil much forsoth cause pope layde charge receiued palle canonically said stigandus deposed shortly councell holden winchester presence ij idē noueobur m pallium canonicè nō suscepisti fabian par 7 cap 220 cause archbishop stigā dus vvas deposed cardinal sent frō pope alexander 2 fabian writeth thre cause first holden wrōgfully bisshoprik whyle robert archbishop liuing second receyued palle benett bishop rome fifth name third occupied said palle without licēce leful authority court rome guil malmesb stigandū perperā falsò archiepiscopū per card rom armenfridū episcopum sedunensem deponi passus est polychronic lib 7 cap 1 author polychronicon writeth like effect neubrigensis also newly prīted toucheth depositiō stigādus pope legat englād ād reporteth pope legat canonically deposed liking haue horne kīg williās supremacy happy fellowes protestāt bishop two archbisshops said williā king ye se cause sufficiēt neub lib 1 cap 1 ye al shuld depriued aswel stigādꝰ yet ther one thīg worse thā schisme heresym horne felovves deposed yf allovv vv conquerours supremacy woulde euer haue thought good reader pope euer haue found horne selfe good proctour papacy againste self fellowes lo brasen face shortly incredible impudency much famouse freer bacon brasen head schollers oxforde wonte talke much doth blushem horn impudē cie tel thee good reader owne confusion pope legate councell kepte winchester al ye wotte wel shewe kinge william supreme head al cause wel temporall spiritual doth pleade foorth full lustely pope kinge william heareth certayne ecclesiasticall matter beinge controuersie dependinge pope cowrte betwene archebisshop yorke archebisshop caunterbury cause pope remitted determined king bishop gul malmesb ex praecepto alexandri 11 ventilata est causa c adfuit hubertus legatus papae fabian cap 222 polich lib 7 cap 3 guiliel de pontifi guil hū tingt well said horne like pope faithfull proctour hereof followeth pope supreame head iudge cause kinge pope commissioner whose commaundemēt cause sent ouer heard englād yet hubertus pope legat present end notwithstāding horne would belike make v belieue king william also thrusted abbats supressed monastery yt pleased telleth v kīgs iudgement abbat thurstan chaunged monk scattered abrode forgotte set also authour others say slaying certayne monkes wounding certayne monk also hurt many men author pollichronicō telleth mōks scattered abrode kīgs hest diuers bisshopriks abbays latter word ye leue also author fabiā saith scattred reporte though bene scattred coates late dayes saieth spred abrode diuers house englande chaunged house religion spirituall matter kinge neither gaue herein iudgement spirituall cause nowe argumentes euidences fayled v shewe kinge william toke self supreame gouernour maner cause moste vntruely fondly auouche might well proue againste yowe storie lanfranke whome kinge williamnotable place lanfrācus pope primacie lanfran contra berengar de sacramēto et hoc impio ore garristi quod garrista nemo loquitur nō haereticus non schismaticus non falsus aliquis christianus fol 2 ye confesse made archebishop canterburie though according olde manner ye dissemble aswell depryuation stigandus whose place king set lanfranke lanfranke receyuid palle rome acknowledged kinge pope supreame head church thing doth manifestly appeare learned boke wrote againste greate graundsier berengarius ye doe nowe denied transubstantiation real presence christes bodie sacramente called churche rome condemned heresie ye vse doe church malignante councell vanitye see sathan whome lanfrancus answereth neuer anie heretyke anie schismatyke anie false christian hym wyckedly babled againste see sayth yet farder place sayd boke quotquot primordio christianae ecclesiae christiani nominis dignitate gloriati sunt etsi aliqui relicto veritatis tramite per deuia erroris incedere maluerunt sedem tamen sancti petri apostoli magnificè honorauerunt nullam que aduersus eam huiusmodi blasphemiam vel dicere vel scribere praesumpserunt whosoeuer begynning christes church fol 13 beati patres cōcorditer astruxerūt haericum esse hoēm omnem qui à romana vniuersali ecclesia sidei doctrina discordat edit lo nan 8 1551 honored name christē mē though forsaking truth haue gone astray yet honoured much see peter neyther presumed time either speake write blasphemy saieth also blessed father doe vniformly affirme mā heretike doth dissent romā vniuersal church matter faith nede lay furth thee good reader lanfrāks learned book goe matter haue hand ministred v horne cōcerning matter sent determined king haue get either polychronicō fabiā would wish see place thā wil meruail horne would shame bring matter agaīst pope primacy confirmation chiefly vsed therfore cōclusion ye inferre premiss ye haue specified haue shewed impugne establish pope primacy fond folish false cōclusion appeareth well fabian polychronicon would sometime like substātial bulwark lib de pō tif angli build newe supreamacy vpō nowe might anie wise mā much meruail cōsider ye haue ladē freighted one page boke lesse 6 quotatiōs polychronicō yet one promotion matth par auncestours doone vvherefore anselme fel vvith kinge vvould consecrate suche prelate beynge lay man made archebishop yorke 418the 418 vntruthe pleasure kinge left consecrate thē cardinall named ioannes cremensis came redresse matter enueighed againste vice vvas selfe nyghte taken tardy councell also sayth polydore kinge prouided many thinges bee enacted shoulde greatly helpe vvilliam sonne whereupon polydorus taketh occasion speake order parliamente though haue french name yet deede councell clergy polidorus polidorus nauclerus abbas vrsp laitie vvhereof prince hath full learned archbishop caūterbury anselme cal hys synodes correcte bishoppes challenged inuestiture bishoppes woulde paye tribute rome ergo quene englande supreame head church englande losenes fondnes thys argumente euery childe may sone espie argument may set pope crowne vppon head wycked heathen prince especiallie tyrāte licinius whome eusebius cōparing good christian emperour constantine cōpartner hym empire ād hys wyckednes writeth thus 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 c first watched obserued priestes god vnder hys gouernemente wheras nothing offended hym curiouse subtyle working deuised pretensed matter trouble vex • themthe agreablenes betvvene rufus ād tyrāt licinius stayyng ecclesiasticall councels could fynd iuste matter accuse withall made proclamatiō bishoppes 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 c maner matter assemble together yt shoulde lawfull repayre theire neighbour church 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 c call synode place consulte debate vppon suche thinges apperteyned commoditye churche thys hys dryfte wich sowght theyre destruction either bishoppes daunger punished▪ yf trāsgressed law yf kepte lawe broke order custome churche could aduise thē selues weighty matter synode thys wicked mā hated god gaue thys commaundement might worke quite contrarye doeinges good constantyne whome god loued reuerēce god suche studie endeuour haue peace agreemente assembled god priest together horne like spider ād flie worthines bisshop anse • guil maelmesb lib de pontif henri • hunting histor angl • e cause dissen • iō betvvene king • ufus anselmus edmerus de vita ansel li 2 regē pro ecclesiarū quae de die diē destruebātur releuatione pro christianae l • gi quae multis violabatur renouatione pro diuersorū morū qui ōni ordine hominum quotidie nimis corrumpebantur correctione coepit interpellare thother cōtrariwyse wēt dissolue thing wel ordeined breke peace ād agreemēt thus farre eusebius heathen tyran licinius ye play therfore horn like spider gathereth nothīg poison sweet herbes doe good chronicle ye like flie loueth dwell horse dong would god reader horne would either aduisedly weigh ill king williā rufus agreable consent writer straūge wōderful tokēs sene time ād ended life slaine glaūsing arrowe hūting excellēt learning cōstancy vertue b anselmus great miracle god wrought wel death set foorth best historiographer time pilling spiritualty ād tēporalty selling bisshopriks bought solde plainly marchandize horne author fabian beside others dothe declare beginning king displeasure bishop anselme rose principally woulde according expectation geue way thanks edmer lib 2 thousand pound making hī archebishop caūterbury yet naught king neuer denyed pope supreme heade iudge church paiment tribut called rome shot time pretending knew true pope church rome thē troubled schisme seeming time fauour rather false true pope vrbane notwithstanding acknowledged true pope edmer dict lib 2 attamen posthaec et vrbanum per vvalterum albanensem episcopum qui palliū à rom anselmo cantuariam detulit pro papa suscepit et principum suorum cōsilio actus amicitiam suam virum recepit ād receiued walter pope legat brought palle anselme receiued anselme also friendship henry huntington writeth king selfe sent palle brought caūterburie set vpon aulter honor peter kissed al men humblie kneeling haue shewed fasshiō king forbod tribut paid rome marueile ye tell rather polichronicō fabian saith well residue ye alleage good dedes henric hunting cap 225 describing death williā telleth day whē died held hand three bisshopriks caūterbury winchester ād salisbury diuers abbey let farme also restrained mony old time paid rome called rome shot al told fabiā chronicler shew couetous man iniurious church shewe practise due laufull authoritie thereby yet serueth notwithstanding horne purpose wel horne wil haue prince like william rufus father conquerour taxe pille spiritualty temporalty realme measure tributs concerning kīg hēry first one bring foorth worthy example new supremacie yet ye fasten vppon neyther edmer lib 2 de vita anselmi post ea omnia regauit anselmum rex quatenus ipsemet romam iret henr hungt rogatus à rege perrexit romam idē hēric hūgt anno 1107 statuit vt nūquā per donationem baculi pastoralis vel ānuli quis quam de episcopatu vel abbatia • er regē vel quamlibet laicā manum anglia inuestiretur • ex antecessorū suorum vsu relicto • ec persona quae regimen ecclesiarum sumebantur per se eligit nec ea per dationem virgae pastoralis quibus praeficie batur inuestiuit edmer lib 2 de vita anselmi much lesse shal ye fasten vpon king henry folowing though time displeased anselme would neyther consecrate bishop communicate king inuestured pope commaunded matter yet stā ding controuersie flie ye write king desire went rome see could mollifie pope afterwarde king perfitly reconciled king made ordinaunce decree time foreward bishop abbat inuestured king laie man pastorall staffe ring writeth henrie archedeacon huntington writer liuing like also edmerius anselmes cōpanion exile writeth king gladde made peace accorde anselme great hope soner subdue normandie euen chaunced notable victorie toke prisoner brother robert prince assisted robert whiche thing certified anselme letter sent englande men day imputed victorie agreamente made anselme tel nowe good faith horne supreme heade king yelded pope inuesturīg idem pope would neuer yelde emperour henrie 4 neither matter omnes qui haec gesta tūc tēporis audiere ea meritis cōcordiae quā rex cū ansel fecerat ascripsere fabian cap 227 excommunicate emperour king henry faine forsake doings though selfe mighty prince emperours father law maude empresse daughter also perceiue horne wil lightly blushm horn sheweth selfe vvorthy punished vvhoredome ovvn storie could ye would neuer shame haue tolde reader priestes punnished whoredome sauing maistres madges poore honestie yet whoredome infinitely excedeth punished keping company concubine wiues whome laufully maried ordered priesthod doe marie neuer allowed euer condemned wel greke churche latine decke margent thicke ye fabiā simeon dunelmens rogerus houedenus henricus huntingtonꝰ matheus parisiēs matheus westmonasteriēs polidorus ād blow horne dishonesty shame long ye see supreamacy ye shal buyld vpon fickle filthy foundation fabian simeon dunelmens rogerus houed rex tenuit conciliū magnū apud lōdonū de vxoribus sacerdotū prohibē li c concessere namque regi iustitiā de vxoribus sacerdotū improuidi habiti sunt accepit enī rex pecuniam infinitam de presbyteris redemit eos similia habet henr huntington verely owne authours doe witnesse king kept great councel london among al decree saieth fabian one priestes forgoe wiues pope legate taken ye write whoredome yet mattheus westmonast writeth priest correctour priest thereby excused fault doth relieue cause wherein doth saue honestie king punish fornicatours clergy consent wherein thier rashe graunte ouerseen circumuented king tooke greate masse money parson faultye dismissed ye tell v nowe polidore parliament dede councel clergie layetie lib 11 order parliamēte abovvt conqueste parliamētum est ex 3 gradibus siue generibus scilicet ex procuratoribus cleri militibus cōmunitatis ciuibus burgensibus qui repraesentāt totam communitatem angliae quia quilibet magnatum est • bi pro propria persona non pro alia ye meane ecclesiasticall councell polydore neither saieth meaneth yt maketh parliamente assemble politike matter prelate also come baron matter ecclesiasticall appointeth specialle conuocation truthe yt conqueste william conquerours tyme appeareth old recordes writen semeth abowt cōquest proctours clergye sate lower howse sayde recordes shewe parliament properly standeth consisteth 3 degree proctours clergye knightes sheere burgeses citizen represent people comminaltie realme noble men bishoppes oth • r owne person yf shal beleue said auncient record nowe though many yeres matter politike cōuocation haue nothing doe yet • paiemēt made taketh place vertue parliamēt clergy onles clergie cōsent yf true mony mater aūciēt time clergy ciuil mater also prerogatiue belik left volūtarely might better attend owne spirituall vocatiō accōpt ought good reason made late parliamentm horn vvisdom reasoning hym selfe wherein mere laie men haue turned vpsidowne state catholique faythe againste full mindes clergie leaue euery wiseman well consider beganne saye polidore meaneth parliamente councell spirituall matter purpose polidorus lib 11 admonebat ne sanctos ritus neuè religionis iura et ceremonias verteret pollueretque great wisedome haue ye alleaged calleth making bisshops ād abbats holy rite lawes religiō church ceremony seing king gaue ouer electing bishoppes seing authour doth shew anselme rebuked king therefore nowe matter englande horne addeth greate vntruthe kyng hungarie tellyng v martinus kynge hungarie vntill time yeare grace 1110 thence euen til day maketh ād inuestureth according pleasure bisshops c thys say great flat vntruth martinus saieth plainly cōtrary thus time king hūgary saieth martinus writing many aduertisements pope letter gaue ouer inuesturing bishop prelats martinus polonus pascha li 2 renunciauit inuestituris episcoporum aliorū praelatorū vntil time kinges hungary wonte make true wordes martinus place passing impudency horne author telleth pope primacy man wresteth prince therefore whereas martinus telleth vntill time kinges hungary inuested bishop addeth farder time kinge hungary gaue ouer pope handes horne bothe lewdely concealeth also owne impudentlye shamelessely addeth thence euen til dayes martinus auoucheth telleth also plainely contrarye witte time king gaue ouer al matter farder make matter soūd princely make martinus say kinge hungary inuested bishop according pleasure wordes according pleasure martinus al poynt descant vpō playne fitte owne volūtary pleasure dede soū ded pleasauntly horne eares exāmple might also goe bishop made prince pleasure remoued againe highnes pleasure hearde forme paschalis graunte made henry 4 though prince haue inuesturing confirming bishoppes graunted yet neuer graūted prince ōly pleasure suffised make man true bishop first prince inuested confirmed vide nauclerū generat 38 pag 183 shoulde liberè praeter violentiam simoniam electus chosen freely without violence simony prince part great faultes emperours germanie kinges oure land inuesturing bishop owne handes namely henrie 4 emperoure william rufus england grieuouslie daily committed secondarelye though inuested confirmed prince dist 63 synod yet post inuestituram canonicè consecrationem accipiant ab episcopo ad quem pertinuerint inuesturing let saith paschalis consecrated bisshop belong likewise leo 8 graūt made otho 1 geuing emperour inuesturing bishop addeth et consecrationem vnde debent consecrated ought word vnde debent ought nonse lefte alleaging graunt made otho thentent inuesturing prince fol 7 • fac 1 without cō secration al metropolitane self poore man bishop neither might seme good sufficient haue example antiquitie purpose also ye make martinus say king hungarie made bishop according pleasure see nowe prince pleasure maketh bisshop must free election without eyther forcing clergy choise forcing chosen filthie bribery also must follow due consecratiō al fellowes doe lacke therefore deede waye conclude true bisshoppes neither lawe churche see 2 • henric 8 cap 14 1 elizab cap 1 neyther especially also note auncient part christēdom southvvard aethiopia conteining 62 kingdomes vnder ruling vvhō vve misname presbyter ioannes vvho say vver priest head bisshop ouer christian realmes hauing povver vvith pope 423 423 vntruth slāderus vsurpatiō hath chalēged europe head vniuersal priest ād king vve may beleue sabellicus vvho saith hath often talked vvith marchaūts haue trafique hath also díuers time enquired matter interpretour inhabitaunts borne al say name neyther presbiter ioannes pretto ianes say name gyan mightie maruaile greatly italian meane call name priesthode say al suite requestes euen greate bishoppes brought king self benefice spiritual promotion opteined handes 424 424 vntruth lewde nipping away vvordes folowing sentence beynge sabellicus telleth called ouer clergy laie cause ecclesiastical themporall gyan mightie supreme ruler ād gouernour ād euē hath 425 425 vntruth neuer able iustified cōtinued sithē partes vvere first christened saye thomas dydimus apostle vntill tyme thys vvaye novv retourne ovvne countrey 20 chapter armenian aethiopians preto ianes lande stapleton man would thinke maister horne straunge spirituall meditation rauishedm horne spiritual rauishmēt sodainly caried frō england moscouia aethiopia c interlaced digression woorthy belike depely cōsidered tel whether impertinently falsely betwene doings king henrie king stephen immediately succeded full wisely wrenched writhed vppon sodaine man rapt vppe caried awaie spaine greece armenia moscouia yea aethiopia sodainly england againe foure hundred yeres past busie busie owne honestie spaine nowe long taciturnitie belike hathe espied notable matter purpose thinke ye good reader forsooth commeth mummerie sendeth v arnoldus de villa noua telleth v shall learne frederike king sicilie iames king spain epistle writen said arnoldus arnoldus heretique catholique bookes printed man shall finde thing telleth v nothing brother gesnerus horn bibliotheca maketh mētion arnoldꝰ phisitiō ād nūbreth bokes epistle word maruel notable worke shoulde escape hys handes suerlye much doe suppose haue chaunced vppon hym brother illiricus frende gaspar hedio addeth paralipomena abbas vrsper gensis haue feeling thys greate ghostly rauishmēte ād feele fyngers endes arnoldus better illiricus maketh hym owne deare brother heretike aswell self also vehemencye thys impertinente madde meditatiō caried away vide paralip vrsperg matheum flaccium illiricum catalogo testium veritatis one hundred fiftie yeares leaste tyme ye shoulde haue orderly prosequuted many myles matter yt self thys arnoldus noted haue writen lyke blinde lewde lying prophete abowte tyme clemente fifte made pope abowte yeare lorde 1306 arnoldus taking vppon prophete sayeth antichrist come within 34 yeres blinde prophesiyng hys part horne also playeth lying prophete imo quod deterius est videtur nobis quod pro nihilo habeant ecclesiam romanam quia nulli appellationi ad eam factae deferunt telleth v wonderfull epistle authour wrote one hundred yeares borne whiche epistle though highe mysticall yet semeth greate poynte heresie thē euer reformation king wente aboute epistle seme geue playn testimony pope primacy fynde faulte certaine religiouse person despised churche rome disallow appeales see yea telleth v greate mighty assertion sayeth quòd concluditur infallibiliter quòd antichristus apparebit mundo ab hoc anno domini 1354 infra immediatè sequentes 34 annos infallible conclusion antechriste shall appeare world within fowre thyrty yeares immediatly folowing yeare lorde 1354 sayth withall within sayde 34 sarasyns destroyed iewes conuerted iurisdictionem summi pontificis per vniuersum orbē dilatari authoritie pope spredde owte worlde well euer yt arnoldus de villa noua seameth greatly furder horne primacy semeth ignorāce taketh one arnoldus bernard epist platina 4 sabel en 9 lib 9 dede one arnoldus brixianus abowt thys tyme cōdemned heretik eugenius 3 bernarde platina sabellicus doe write brother bale sayeth condemned sayde clergy might vse temporal iurisdictiō thys arnoldus might haue serued turne tyme somwhat matter accustomable reasoninge authority heretikes maye serue turne let arnoldus ād spayne goe tyme horne hath great coūtries time taketh hys part grecia armenia moscouia ād aethiopia acknouledge theyre prince theyr supreame gouernours al thing next vnto god ye muste belieue without proufe belyke yt shewed horne thys spirituall reuelation otherwise assured shall neuer iustifie vntrewe saying though perchaunce coū treis tyme shewe see rome suche obediēce owght haue done especially greciās ād moscouites followe religiō order greke church yet neither doth horne proue euer shall able proue church coū try gaue suche authoritie theyre prince euer toke spirituall cause theyre patriarche bishoppes supreame heades matter spirituall maruayle nowe yt horne loke vpon grecian armenian one blind eye bleared affection heresie hatred pope otherwyse yf woulde loke vppon better indifferente eie cause whie regarde aswell aunciente greeke churche acknowledged pope supreamacye also later acknowledging generall councell lion wherof haue spoken also afterward general coūcel ferraria frō thēce trāslated florēce also armenian ioyned roman church first anno 1145 nauclerus generat 39 pag 231 volater geograph lib 10 otho frising three hundred yeres aboute 10 yeres deathe henry first bernardes tyme armenian submitted selues eugenius 3 sending chief metropolitane vnder moe thē thousand bishop see rome trauayling iourney yere ād halfe came viterbū scarse ij dayes iourney rome pope lay thē whō receyued ād instructed al thinges sought handes touching order blessed sacrifice obseruation festiuall dayes certayn pointes wherin varyed rest christendome errours cōc nicen 2 cap 32 theophil ioan 19 niceph li 18 cap 52 53old writer much ād oftē noted submissiō church rome fel tyme horne talketh affirming falsly maner people armenia acknowleged none ōly prince supreme gournours neither neded yow yet horne haue loked far enuious eie might haue abiddē late time late councel trent ye haue found armenian sent ambassadours pope recognising hys supreamacy desiring confirmation theyre patriarch antiochia ye haue founde abdisa patriarche assyrian inhabiting nygh famous floud tygris came rome small eyther trauell daunger hys life confirmed pius quartus last pope blessed memorie also promised well hym selfe vnder spiritual gouernemēt woulde faythfully constantly keepe suche decree set forth saied councell trent perchaunce ye lesse passe armenian seeyng haue syde ye saye thys tyme greate prince aethiopians hauing lesse 62 kingdomes vnder hys dominion country beyng auncient part christendome southwarde selfe haue forsaken priesthodde take heede pray ye haue withall forsaken christendome ye contented italian call hym prieste ihon thoughe prieste head bishoppe ouer christian realmes hauing suche power wyth pope vsurpation ye terme yt hath challenged europe head vniuersall priest kyng ye would rather called sabellicus telleth mighty gyan called ye mighty lying exposition falsly declare supreme ruler gouernour cause aswel ecclesiasticall tēporal first seing ye pretend selfe good antiquarie would gladly knowe monumentes ye haue aethiopical religion time bene mete ye laied foorth authour discharge surely beleue ye haue sene none al antiquitie dare boldly auouch ye neither haue shal see whereby ye may iustly gather aethiopiās take king supreme head cause ecclesiastical temporal haue contrary confession bishop raba rago king embassadour king portugale domianꝰ à go de aethiopum moribus pontificem romanum tanquam primum episcopum pastorem ouiū christi agnosco nostri certè ab exordio primitiuae ecclesiae rom pontificē vt primum episc agnouerūt cui etiam hodierno die vt christi vicario paeremus anno dom 1524 propterea dico ego humiliter ad terram flexis genibus quòd tu pater meus e ego filius tuus procul dubio sanctitas vestra dei est vicarius made 33 yeares past saying doth acknowledge bisshop rome chief bishop pastour christes shepe haue confession wherein declareth aethiopiās euē frō begīning church acknowlege b rome first ād chief bisshop ād day obey christes vicar speak orator cōfession haue king cōfessiō made pope wherin calleth hī caput oīū pōtifi • ū head al bisshops saith pope aequū est vt omnes obedientiā tibi praestent sicuti sancti apostoli praecipiūt mete al men obey euen thapostles commaund saith humbly kneling ground pope father sonne saith holines without al doubt god vicar thinke ye horne ye shal like mighty giant cōquer al reader ād make bōnd slaues ignorāce folly sabellicus sayeth called mightye cyan therefore yee maye mightely lye conclude thereby hathe collection spiritual liuinges therfore supreame gouernour cause horn sabel ene 10 lib 8 shal greate falshood discouered lying sprite coniured beholde euen immediatly word alleaged sabellicus al benefice spiritual promotion obtayned king hand foloweth say immediatly quod rom pontifex regum maiestati dederit thinge bisshop rome hath geuen king maiesty woordes authour haue lewdely nipped quyte à macariā lyke iewel pewefellowe neither doth speake order relligion age many hundred yeres paste ye pretende late tyme thus horne longe fruitles iorney wherin wayfaring men longe iorneyes wonte doe mat par polychro ye haue gathered store wonderfull lie delight hearer haue trauayled ye recite one thē ye may proue new supremacy therby hard wisest man coūtrey tel yea much rather yt serueth cōtrary proueth pope supremacy disallowed said article many king also beīg lēgth fain pope ther thre thē cōdēned 1 3 ād 4 thre pope suffer ād tolerat againe decree none held king capite seruāts shuld excōmunicated onlesse kīg first cōsulted trow horn hīself ād fellowes arthure able kepe possessiō owne realme saxon caried armie one hundred thousande farre country hauing vnder conducte nomber kinges slewe emperour rome ād discomfited huge army wherin aboue 5 6 tel v spare mōk swīstead otherwise wer swyneshead would lightly rashly perswaded suche swynish fable paynt ād picture thē fast ād fayre ye wil make fooles fayn withal say wil excuse hym yll monke theyre nawghty doinges require cōuenient proufe namely foxe fellowes precise catholikes proufes ye haue al proued ye proue nothing purpose ill doings naughty packes neither deface truth catholique doctrine yet spotte honestie cō senting likelihode king sort poisoned incredible monke mass continually songe soule incredible shoulde confirmed generall chapter foxe thinke carie awaye matter thinke al reade foolish lewd lying martyrologe straight way without tryall examination take gospell see god hath prouided false lying fable good conuenient remedie willingly caried away lyke fooles beastesan great vnvntruth fox authour hath vvord confirmatiō see thys boke prynted vvinkin de word • 2502 discredite fable seeing selfe hath impudently added authour concerning confirmation generall chapter catholike fayth paterans men prompte redie suffer death howbeit wretched paterans hauing holie belief eternall deitie theyre owne wickednes offende three together god theyre neighbour selues god saye while knowe faythe shoulde haue god counsayle deceyue theire neighbour while vnder pretēce spirituall ghostly feadinge feade pleasaunt wicked heresie cruell selues while beside losse theire sowles subiection counted muche better heretyke marsilius patauinus hath bene aswell long agoe also late largely learnedly answered writer marsilius patauinus ockam dante petrarche diuerse others part brethern basil haue patched vp togeather greate volume laboure al proue emperour aboue pope temporal iurisdiction gouernemēt wherin yet erred haue said none thē al doe labour proue emperour supreme gouernour spirituall ecclesiastical cause first founder heresy say sweare leaue bishoppes yea pope therefore al true wrote fauoure lewys 4 emperour yet neuer nerer purpose one iote horne owne proper singular heresy england make prince supreme gouernour cause ecclesiastical laicocephali make lay magistrate head spirituall matter ye adde force matter great coū cel kepte franckford wherat king beame englande also presente wyth thing set forth special ād latin letter precise word marius additiō adioyned vrspergensis neither anye marginall authours speake king englād ye haue al ād euer yt schismatical conuenticle yet muche better late conuocations yf article sayde conuocations comme theire handes dowbte bene condemned greate parte blasphemous heresy wel emperour saith say authority depēdeth pope god immediatly vayne thinge wonte sayde pope hath superiour yf ye could proue emperour euangelist coūcel lawfull generall councel would geue eare yf themperours authority depende immediatly god shewe v goddes commaundement geuē rather german frenche english mē chose emperour prince christiā europa holde succession electiō yf ye cā shew v cause diuersity pope ordinance shal ye quite self lyke clerke yf ye cā shewe cause shal ye neuer able shewe v good cause pope clayme cōfirmation yet yt sayeth hornem horne leaueth owte authours vvordes vide dict paralip naucler relieued ye yet againe hand councel frankford emperour certaine heresy pope clement laid emperours charge would make wise man wonder consider end ād purpose stuffe thrust neither cause yet coniecture maketh thē ye bable tēporal matter abridgeth clergy iurisdiction therein onely reproueth certayne abuse therin committed forthe clergy promised reformation let v nowe see policie ād benefit cause ye doe lie imagyne yf ye wil al true ād one take philip french king law made cacus denne good force yf yt ben made open parliament france issue ioyne thereofm horn impertinent argument due ordinate king fraunce england duke ireland offereth deuoutly kisse holy feete pensatae etiā deuotionis plenitudine quam domꝰ nostra regia clerus ac populus dicti regni praestiterūt hactenus obedientia dictae personam vestrā sanctiss sanctam rom ecclesiam dominari cupimus vt debemus c desire euen dutie holy person holy churche rome might gouerne rule horne vnlesse vppon sodayne newe deuotiō ye intende haue pope beare rule england againe also offer selfe yf neede kysse pope fote wich thing great mighty prince ashamed say tell v shame letter neither tel v disorder reformed nowe almost two hundred yeares agoe make thereby vnseasonable fonde argumente abolishe pope authority dayes effecte letter pray humbly pope woulde reseruations collation prouisions archbishoprykes bishoprykes abbeis priory bicause may alwaies appeled frō iudgmēt synod see apostolik reade saith patriarch cōstātinople flauianus ignatius ād athanasius alexādria reade thei appealed frō synod bishop see apostolik also culmina tenent king supreame head churche assente necessarie synodes bishop coūcelles wil say cōtrary wil much better gathered allegatiō firste wordes wōderfully acrase newe primacy somwhat also honesty peruersly trāslating nōnunquā somtime thē oftētimes let yt nonnunquam sepe let oftētymes haue highest authoritye churche vnlesse haue yt styll called supreame heades cause ecclesiastical theis word make good argumēt againste primacy vt per eandē potestatem ecclesiasticam disciplinā muniant caterū intra ecclesiam potestates necessariae non essent nisi vt quod non preualent sacerdotes efficere per doctrinae sermonē potestas hoc imperet per disciplinae terrorem et mox vt qui intra ecclesiam positi cōtra fidē disciplinā agunt rigore principum cō • arantur horne cause whie haue high authority either somtimes oftētimes isidore straytwayes sheweth cause may self translate fence theire power ecclesiastical discipline ye heare thē scope final purpose allegation prince authority matter ecclesiasticall defende churche therefore sayde yt sutely reade tradidit defendendam tradidit cōmittendā cause emperours call selues caput ecclesiae heades churche sed aduocatos ecclesiae aduocates churche self tel themperour friderike goe forth isidorus first aske horne make prince heades churche haue muche doe matter ecclesiasticall bishop decree nothing shoulde auaylable withowt theyre special ratification setting forth doctrine ye content tyme priestes shalbe priestes may sweare priesthod theire aldermanship eldership whether suche authority prince absolutelie necessarie churche yf ye say thē conclud self ād whole boke yf ye say yea conclude truthe againste authour sayeth suche authority prince church necessarie punishe contemne worde doctrine fayth discipline churche whome haue receiued horne worde doctrine faythe discipline churche apostle theire successours bishoppes prince suppose ye saie prince must ye graunt matter primacy resteth clergy prince thē selues haue receiued theire faith ād matter faith discipline churche must also obey case requireth set forth doctrine worde wyth theire temporal sworde whiche suffer throwghe theire slacknes faythe disciplyne churche loosed god horn • booke manner ansvvered ovvn allegation hath committed churche defended theire power wil exacte accompte thē authour isidore writeth self allege see euen allegatiō superiority churche matter remayneth clergy prince heades ayders assisters aduocates churche theire tēporal authority ende euer ye haue browght boke cōcerning intermedling prince church affaire cā referred allegatiō aswel sufficiēt answere al argumēts hitherto laid furth prince supremacy good iustification clergy primacy wherfore harken owne allegation stande wil reader placing haue said fore fronte booke must nedes stand also next parcell folowing making clerely clergy superioritie ecclesiasticall cause word mean isidorus withī church power prīces shuld necessary sauing thing priest able word doctrine power prīce may cōmaūd terror discipline doubt nothing able wel surely proue wel bookes gathering councels together one volume yet extāt isidorus thought pope primacy catholiques doe euident proufe wherof behold auncient learned bisshop isidorus writeth saith synodorum congregandarum authoritas apostolicae sedi commissa est isidorus praefat cōciliorū neque vllam synodū generalem ratam esse credimus aut legimus quae non fuerit eius authoritate congregata vel fulcita hoc authoritas testatur canonica hoc ecclesiastica historia comprobat hoc sancti patres confirmant authoritie assembling coūcelles committed see apostolike neither doe beleue reade general councell ratified whiche either assembled confirmed authoritie authoritie canon doth witnesse trip li 4 cap 9 19 ecclesiastical history proueth holie father confirme lo see horne iudgement isidorus aboue 900 yeres past howe iumpe agreeth assertion catholiques directly ouerthroweth therfore sure principle parte clerelie proued bethinke selfe horne new primacie wil proued allegation touching saie clergie king henry day diuines also wisest expert best learned ciuil canon lawes hath ben sence tonstal stokesley gardiner thirlbie bonner euident falsehood whiche practise alleaging witness man may iudge fidelitie haue handled rest throughout whole booke ignoraunte one reuerent father sincerely thinke true impute vnto whereas vpright iudgement shoulde come man owne free choise stained spotted either hope priuate lucre honoure feare great losse one two thing forceably carieth men away professing owne conscience stoppe men saying vttering otherwise would gladly haue vttered sithens put hope al promotion agreed king made iudge lesse accompte disagreeing certaine loose bothe good life also good name shew worlde shoulde haue bene put deathe name traitours whiche thing true subiectes doe chieflie abhorre yet knowe suche sorte suffered great many notable learning vertue fisher bishoppe rochester syr thomas great number carthusian beside diuerse estate knowe also matter sifted tryed learning hath bene since know secrete snake adder broode induced king minde doctours named againste willes condescended therevnto howe broughte foorthe witness heresy feare deathe saied doe longer foresaid impedimente laie theyr waye state worlde otherwise without feare deathe might vtter minde freely knoweth liued see day freedome theire woordes deedes protested pope king head churche vnder christ neuer hearde horne owne brother arryued gardiner bishope winchester chauncelour england saied lerned theyr disobedience vnto poped gardiner b vvinchester booke de vera obedientia c aunswered bene good scholers would haue folowed theyr maister beste worste doeinges againe erred authority whē wel learned grounded much repēt recāt authority nowe better lerned longer studie better grounded longer experience doctour gardiner moste side one matter yet suspected deathebedde caused passion christe readen vnto hym hearde readen peter denying maister went wepte bitterlie causyng reader staye wept selfe full bitterlie saied ego exiui sed non dum fleui amarè haue lotharius kinge fountayne iurisdiction meane lotharius doth churche ciuill magistrate vnder kinge said quintinus saieth gladium pontifex vtrū que gestat exercet alterum rex solus quem pontifex etiam desertus suis hostes licitè stringit pope hath swordes temporall spiritual iurisdiction yet king alone vseth one thē tēporal pope may notwithstāding yf forsakē vse also tel quī tinus saith probauimus ecclesiam deo militantem se noluisse temerè negotijs secularibus implicare temporalem que iurisdictionem principibus sponte reliquisse vvhy speculator saith al ī realm king • iurisdictiō tam que libenter tam que animo prompto facili vt regū propria videatur id circo scriptum est à speculatore quòd quicquid est regno id esse intelligitur de iurisdictione regis haue proued militant church doth vpō good cause intermedle seculer affaire yea rather geueth ouer prince temporall iurisdiction gladly willinglye yt seemeth appertayne prince onely ecclesia vtrū que gladiū tenet vtramque pariter habet iurisdictionē therefore speculatour writeth euer kingdome vnderstanded kinges iurisdiction persuaded spirituall temporall iurisdiction stode contrarie one one man might exercise quintinus hīself misliketh opinion saith euen said place nouimus vtrum que gladium solo ecclesiae datum hoc est ecclesiae pontificem habere ius potestatem spiritualia simul omnia temporalia que ex ijs decernere statuere ex causa posse cuius decretis standum gibere deformem flagitiosissimꝰ quidam postea tam infenso nebulone speaketh speculator church ād prince seculer hath swordes iurisdictions vpon occasion doth vehemently inueighe petrus de cugnerio whome haue spokē stifflye stand frēch clergy tēporall iurisdictiō prouoked king philip valesius much laye plucke away frō clergie calleth misshapen parson body wicked mā say al one knaue thoughe name terrible thowgh would seeme great wisedome carrie al realme vpō shulders yet euer lawghing stock mē durst shame great challēge shew hīself abrode wont peter de cugnerioquintinꝰ declareth horn li •• story kīg philip valesius rehersed called tong pierre de coyner mā would say peter lurketh corner wil ye heare horne vntruths • orn lesse • en 15 lynes feuda • ēporalia quae que bona propria sibi possidere posse que illa iurisdictionē habere gaue sentēce pronoūced church might possesse fealtes temporal thing ād learned lavvier great mainteinour pope iurisdiction hath declared opinion agreable pope ovvne lavves prince may take vppon gouerne ecclesiastical 495the 495 vntruth hath bene proued quintinꝰ sēce acte attributeth prince l quicunque de episcopis et clericis quicūque residē • ibus sacerdotibus fuerit episcopali loco mine detrusus si aliquid cōtra quie tē publicā moliri c matter cause stapleton processe following tendeth proue prince haue gouernemente cause matter ecclesiastical might perchaunce stande horne worde gouernemente suppose iustified thing shall bringe forthe wil nede greatly sticke terme wil rather consider thing yt self first ye enter horne vntruth two properly speake neither prince reherse iudges cause ecclesiastical thowgh therein certain intermedling neither dothe lawe ye speake tel bishoppes deposed emperours arcadius honorius this▪ onely bishop deposed fellowe bishoppes assembled together councell howe shalbe ordered yf fownde afterwarde attempte anie thing common wealth concerning doeinges emperour iustinian matter ecclesiasticall dictum ep inter claras de suma trininitate vt nō vestrae innotescat sanctitati quia caput est omnium sanctarum large alredie ye terme moste christian amongest prince learned ecclesiastical discipline doe belieue calling pope iohn ye speake heade churche verie place alleaged gouernance matter ecclesiasticall praye kinge childebertus pope pelagius auoyde slaunder suspicion thinke wel chalcedon councell sent saied king requeste tenoure faythe beliefe therefore doe abuse reader abuse also woorde exacte whiche signifieth constraine compel dyd kinge dyd require demaunde touching emperour charles suppose sufficiently answered alrerdye nothing answered youre selfe nowe alleage maie serue good answere maketh newe rule constitution churche matter establissheth reneweth olde saieth wil compell men lyue according rule canon father neither doothe call selfe heade gouernoure churche deuoute defender humble helper speaketh worldlie kingdome calleth selfe gouernour kingdome fraunce nede answere lewys emperour charles great sonne haue already answered neither touching leo 3 yf ye say emperour iudge alijs praelat besydes lavviers vvas common opinion chiefest vvriters cōmon lavv realme appeareth 496the 496 vntruth contrary appeareth plainely braughton shal declared braughton vvoordes sunt sub rege c vnder king bothe freeman bondemen subiect power vnder certaine thing creature vnder none onely vnder god againe chapiter title vvhereof rex non habet parem c king hath peere equall kingdome king saith kingdom hath equall might lose precepte authoritie commaunding sithe equall hathe rule commaundement ouer equall king himselfe ought vnder man vnder god vnder law law maketh king let king therefore attribute vnto lawe lawe attributeth vnto himthe 487 vntruth parte sentence opening ansvvering vvhole obiection nipped quite wit dominion power king law doth rule ought vnder law cùm sit dei vicarius sith vicare god appeareth euidently likenes iesu christe whose vicegerent earth vvithin litle concludeth thus igitur non debet maior esse eo regno suo 497 therfore ought none greater kingdome 40 chapter concerning braughton maister horne last authour stapleton happie horne writeth english english men latine surelye oure countrie hath shutte pope authoritie yea ād al maner ecclesiastical authority shal passe ocean sea towarde may al nation muche better exclude authority temporall lawyer realme passe sayde ocean sea toward christian belief pity become late nothing else parliamēt matter matter commō lawe seing haue estraunged self olde cōmon catholike faith late vpstart priuate national fayth owne yet colour wil pretend least aunciente faythe realme wil make none exceptiō againste horne plea wil ioyne issue cope euen lawe owne authour horne shall say deale hardly pinchingly freely liberally offer tried pope feare premunire iudges kinges benche al quenes may iudges yea lawyer realme cōmon lawe realme braughtons time king taken head churche pope horne may proue contrary assertiō braughton dare offerre fekenhams name shal take othe wil self dare promise much ād wil performe shalbe contēte withal horne highe inuentiō shal made sergeant quo also saieth mayster horn meane say plainly alleage braughton wordes kinge vnder none onely vnder god kinge hath peere equall ought none greater kingdome kinge yea conclude vicar god braughtons wordes misreherse sayeth mayster horne ye haue saie forsoth mayster horne loke three litle wordes ye proue v owt brawghton kinge greatest realme vicar matter cyuill willinglye graunte matter ecclesiasticall wherof ye haue yet owte braughton browght much one worde haue ioly fetche fetched nothing purpose haue fished braughton vayne yet one thing loke haue honester man betterhovv vvretchedlie horne alleageth brauhgton vppright dealing conscience ye reporte braughton haue hope proue nothing new primacie shall proue euen owne authour common lawe realme pope cheif head christes churche thincke thowghe texte nothing duskishe darke hornelight vnfaythfull blinde allegation yet margent appereth glistering day starre sonne hande open disclose worlde bright beames cleare light catholyque faythe shyning youre owne authoure either exceding malice palpable grosse darke ignorance wherewith desertes spitiful heart catholyke faith god hath plagued lesse aegiptians horne hath braughtō thē title de papa archiepiscopis alijs prelatis pope archbishop prelats nothing bare naked title sayeth braughton text doth say pope hath nothing doe owne diocese bishoppes haue doth say head superiour al bishopes doth say ye saie ecclesiasticall iurisdiction commeth king doth say kinge aboue pope head churche selfe wel ye haue seene starre light margent nowe shall ye see also braughtō lib 1 homines quidā sunt excellētes prelati alijs principantur dominus papa rebus spiritualibus quae pertinent ad sacerdotiū sub eo archiepiscopi episcopi alij praelati inferiores item tēporalibus imperatores reges c vtter destruction newe primacie great dishonestie detestable dealing bright daye light ye tel v braughton al aswel freeman bondman subiecte kinge power tel v king hath peere tel withall title pope archebishope serueth verely serueth direct v confusion shame ye tolde v euen page leafe kinge childebertus exacted pope pelagius confession faith whiche voluntarily offered suerly cōfessiō matter wil come frō freely voluntarily must exacted brought verie violence moste stronge forcible truth let v heare whereof apperteyneth kinges prince defende kingdome ergo non debet maior esse regno suo exhibitioneiuris whiche clergie shoulde intermedle seeing iurisdictions sondred distincted vnlesse yt one sworde muste helpe truste maister horne ye doe may vnderstand meante braughton calleth kinge vicar god saieth ought none greater kinge kingdome whiche rule woulde haue bene playner ye added three woordes saxon coming england thē called pope primacy clerely confessed practised euen day amonge catholikes euery gouernement william conquerour william rufus sonne kinge henry first hath bene proued farre
