shal appeare vvould haue simple conceiue vvay amplification much diuersitie euen vvhich ye call second chiefe point varieth 512 512 vntruthe varieth muche vvhitte matter first therefore former ansvveare serueth ye vvil needes make tvvo shevv dede one first chapter conteyning fekenhams first reason taken actes apostle way king lucius stapleton hitherto hath horne twēty ful leaues enlarged proufs touchīg cō firmatiō newe ecclesiastical superiority hitherto hath assaide al force beate ground pope primacy yet notwithstāding al terrible assaulte standeth strōg sure euer yea trust strōger ād surer withal indifferētly haue perused ād waighed two former labour thē horn wil playe lustly defendātm horne novv begīneth play defendāts parte wherin seemeth make light al fekenhās argument take thē strength thē weight fether seing hath alredy takē many foyles many woundes semeth weapon haue rashe hardines wel beaten himselfe setting vpon aduersarie hard yt beare blowes aduersary wil bestowe vpō neither thinke good reader shall euer soyle men reason soundly sothly confirme owne yet let v trie howe wil shifte self see howe euen first entraunce playeth fowle playe wrangleth fekenham doth make difference betwixte testifie conscience declare conscience maister horne sayeth dothe betwixte take othe queenes maiesty supreame heade cause declare conscience two thing man maye many doe pity take othe feare loue rewarde quyte contrary cōscience nede seke farre example euen matter supremacy nowe hande withal though therefore mā may perswaded many pitie pretence obedience feare displeasure loue worldly promotion rich pleasure take othe yet declare conscience man possibly maister fekenham trulye reasoneth without manifest periury except conscience persuaded thereunto persuade conscience requireth either soden reuelation miraculouse inspiration god presumed without euident signe thereof el tract time instructed informed taught neuer lerned fekenham therefore ād al feare god haue lerned ghospell forsake father mother wyfe child good landes al worlde dere christes sake euery truth concerning christian religion say neither inspired god soden reuelation neither preaching writing yet informed instructed possibly though thousand act parliament commaund declare conscience declare say conscience hart thought beleue verely supreme gouernement prince act expresseth intēdeth mē may perswaded take othe externall fact external respect force feare fraylty perswaded declare othe conscience man without internall persuasion hart minde cō trary internall perswasion consent whiche power prince force act law statut worldly euer make euer declareth externallye booke othe worde mouth thinketh incurreth manifestly horrible crime periurie ād double periurie god wil neuer suffer vnreuēged without hartie repētance strōg inuincible reasō horn answereth word maketh reader beleue fekenham putteth difference betwen testifiyng cōscience declaring cōscience doth thus betwene testifiyng boke othe declaring conscience putteth true difference haue said largely well horne hath pleaded perswade fekenhams conscience thou seest good reader thou haue diligētly read cōferred proufes confutation doubt many catholike men wil perswaded conscience least neuer take othe whiche singularlie contrarie christendome beside doe defende handleth storie themperour philip come good horne declare v surely good reader neuer beare came stake worse maister horne wil come nigh point come one nigh shal forthwith declare selfe void empty regni vero 13 verae religionis amore ductus cū eleutherio romano pontifice egit vt se ac suos ad christianorū numerū coelesti sonte perfusos adiungeret missi sunt eò fugatius ac damianus viri pietate singulari hij regē cum tota domo populo que vniuerso baptisarunt sublatoque c towcheth pope eleutherius lucius sayeth polidore yeare lorde 182 yeare reigne 13 verie true loue religion sent letter eleutherius pope procure people might made christian fugatius damianus men singular vertue sente thither baptise kinge al courte people hath horne broken cutte myddle sentence thereby hath mangled torne miserablie euer medea chylde well sawe yt made notablye pope primacy whiche shall well perceyue yf doe deaplye consider cause moued kynge sende farre rome see good reader sincere honest dealing horne consideration cause moued lucius send rome man woulde firste sight thinke doinges king straunge namely considering abowt time liued fraunce great clearke bishoppe ireneus many famouse men whose ayde might haue craued necessary instruction christian faith neither lacke home owne subiectes could well yt semeth haue serued turne yet doubte good kinge good substantial grownde doinges cōsidered anon death christe euer vntil lucius time amonge christian number heretikes whiche bore name christian theyre heresy loste benefitte christēdome simonians schollers simon magus menandrians saturninians basilidians nicolaites heretikes called gnostici excellent knowledge pretended haue aboue mē cherinthians cerdoniās phrygian montanistes marcionites diuerse eche secte contending theire owne false faith true niceph li 4 c 19 onely christian faith yea manie taken prophetes montanus others many suffred death christe catholike great pacience among priest called metrodorus marcionite idem li 3 cap 36 secte euen lucius time great number suffred persecution raised christian whereof secte craked muche euseb li 5 cap 16 made thereof great argument true faith muche better argumēte doth mayster foxe madde martyr died moste wilfullie playne open heresie lucius vnderstāding good cause careful receiued christendome least chauncing vppō false shrew taking instructour might rather chaunge one errour put yt cleane away idolatour become false christian wante good choyse instructours cause valens emperour became arrian suche horrible bloudsucker catholikes also cause gothes ād vādales arriās cruelly afflicted martyred thowsandes christian sureste way lucius auoyde daunger dowbtles toke send churche rome neuer erred faith principal churche al church muste agree reason cheif principalitie churche ireneus blessed bishop martyr wrote euen tyme lucius principalitie say hath troubled horne durst truely reporte owne authour yea amased falling sodēly rage hath framed v suche open maliciouse lie euer wil hereafter truste well worthie beguiled wil ye yet see greate madnes man moste shamefully denieth theis doinges lucius pope eleutherius againste vniforme cōsente al historiographer hath fownde letter lucius eleutherius answerecōcernīg pope eleutherius letter king lucius wherof one al foresayde chronicler maketh mention cā yet lerne containinge matter altogether vnprobable vnlikely therefore mete fowrtene hundred yeares nowe length come owte trophonius cacus blinde denne set horne boke notable matter antiquity furnish bewtify new supremacie withal layeth v forth epistle eleutherius authour hath taken yt library shal fynde yt tell v best author wene alleage wil recordes parchement guild halle iewel wil answere meievvell pag 86 reply horne calues skinne sufficient warrant truth lie haue bene writen letter golde wel make best iustifie may cause take preiudice shal take much shame matter selfe yet least three foure pretie lie adioyne companie notable epistle first neuer saxon king made notable lawes called iune one called inas dede king aluredus alphredus ordeined many lawes shoulde suche scripture lawes maister horne saieth drawen alonely scripture mayster horne vaine dreame case great regarde scripture onely measured squared lawes doings scripture belike horne beginne haue better liking religious men pope primacye also king inas nauclerus putat hunc fuisse edeluulphum alphredi patrem generat 29 pag 61 alibi vocat eum adulphū gener 41 pag 280 henricus hunting asserius meneuēs pol li 4 pag 89 gaue peter penny first rome renouncing realme went rome professed self monke thing vndoubtedly horn must nedes find scripture alphredus anointed crowned king rome haue told therfore called pope sonne adoptiue wheras ye bring imbeciled wild beastes deuowred shepeherd horne doth onely feede sheepe carefully choseth owte suche grownde pastour moste conueniente holsome besides sondreth whole sownde infected rottē greaceth tarreth byndeth cutteth hath staf hooke draw thē stray hath staf beat away wolfe hath folde close shutte vp saufe incursiōs woulf ād rauening beast doth resemble expresse vnto v pastorall office must sweare vpon euangelists foraine personne state potentate hath ought haue power authoritie ecclesiastical spiritual within realme also vertue othe must renounce forraine power authority christian man doe directly two article crede credo sanctā ecclesiā catholicā beleue holy catholik • hurch credo sanctorū cōmunionē beleue cōmuniō saint participatiō cōmunion amongest al beleuers christes church apostle paule called saincts adiuro vos per dominū vt legatur haec epistola omnibus sanctis fratribus herin ioyne issue l whā l shalbe able proue scripture doctor general coūcell cōtinual practise one church part al christē dome first article beleue holy catholik church meant catholike church christ article euery christiā man bound subiect obedient catholike church like euery member ought haue obediēce vnto whole mystical bodie christ shall hable proue second article dooe beleue communion saint meante christian man oughte beleeue attonement suche participation communion amongest al beleeuers member christes catholike churche doctrine faith religion sacramentes laufull v realme therein dissent catholike churche christe dispersed realmes corporal othe laufull v renounce refuse haue communion catholike church dispersed bycause forrayne authoritie power realme soeuer l shalbe hable proue scripture doctour generall councell yet continuall practise one church parte al christendome shal lyke manner yelde third point humble thankes shal thinke selfe well satisfied therein horne thirde chiefe pointe 541 541 vntruth conteineth argumēt horne shal neuer assoyle beinge rightly vnderstanded christian doth doubte vvill denie laste huge heape flatte manifeste 542 542 vntruth slaunderous iniurious lye againste vvhole realme set good face vppon euill fauoured feeble reason grounded simple skill vppon place ab oppositis pugnantibus aunsvvere argument vvill put reader remembraunce diuision vvhiche make chopping chaunginge one 543 543 vntruth 2 diuers article one clemēs compend de fide article tvvaine make shevve heinous matter surely vvere ouermuche detestable vvere moued svveare one article creede yee vvere neuer moued either fro svveare anie thinge three symboles creedes vvhiche haue bene allovved receaued christes catholique churche symbole apostle nicen councell athanasius apostolicall called bycause vvas collected saye tvvelue apostle therefore conteineth commonly receiued opinion christes churche according number tvvelue apostle tvvelue article vvhiche called vsuall speache catholique christian tvvelue article creede beliefe beleue communion sainctes seuerall article beleue holy catholique churche doe phantasie muste needes leaste thirtene article creede contrarie 544 544 vntruth cōmō opiniō lerned mē rekoneth thē 12 therfore vntruly ād lesse vnskilfully babled one directly vvhen yong scholer hath red rudimēts logik could haue sene iudged ther thē oppositiō repugnancy al renoūce ād forsake 547 547 vntruth cōmuniō sainctes faithful one haue ben shalbe novv one liue earth hovve vvhersoeuer diuided dispersed time place vvhich multitude saintes haue participatiō cōmuniō amōgst thēselues al good thing geuē graūted grovvīg frō god christ spirit faith sacramēts praier remissiō syns heauēly blisse vnited christ head faith fastened together amōgst thēselues mēbers one body vvith bōd faith religiō sacramēts neither realme may laufully dissent frō church renoūce refuse haue cōmunion therevvith god praised vve realme novve shevve selues al christiā meanes neuer time 548 548 iurisdictiō euery forain prelat exclude ād renoūce whol body church without realm cō sisteth ꝓperly ād effectually bishop ād prelats head therof tēporal iurisdictiō othe bindeth al subiects state therof beīg chāgeable ād mutable euē spiritual ecclesiastical iurisdictiō othe expressely renounceth al power ād autority forain prelats al prelats ād bishop world beside wolde mete brittaynes selues venerable bede recordeth neither willing receaue lewde doctrine neither able refute theire wyly wicked persuasion deuised holsome councell seke ayde bisshoppes frāce spirituall betwene euery foraine prelate othe speaketh catholike churche seing haue often said catholyk church consisteth euery forayn prelate without realme englād much al prelate within realme englād yea though euery foraine prelate without realme england may haue many general councells prescribed ouer al bishoppes england yet bishoppes england nether haue may tyme prescribe ouer euery foraine prelate without realme england othe therfore excludeth plainely authority catholike church fighteth directly good reason order horn definitiō churche horn church cōpared schismatical temple samaria iosephus hose serueth euery legge simon magus marcion hebion manicheus photinus arrius nestorius al sect euer graunt definition wil therby challenge church sect ye herein synagoge resembleth faulse schismatical tēple onias made aegypte sanaballites samaria mount garizim wherof ghospel iohn speaketh though yt doth expresly name though god specially appointed temple hierusalē true holy temple would al sacrifice offred yet samaritanes toke temple true temple god would honored sayed offering sacrifice made ther hierusalem iewes sayth iosephus vnlawfully maried transgressed violated sabbot day eaten meates thing contrary lawe fearing punishment would fly samaritanes false bishop complaine wrongfully vexed hierusalem ioyne sayd schismaticall factiō temple garizim sayth iosephus continuall strief contention betwene iewes samaritanes lib 12 ca 1 ant eche parte much sturre busines preferring auauncing owne temple yea matter went farre samaritanes waxed hotte feruent length euer honored great rewardes enriched temple god true temple whervppon proctours samaritanes kinges commaundement put death whome notwithstāding samaritan toke blessed martyr foxe taketh ragged rablement new holy • tyrologe schismatical synagog patern church horne sentence hath bene geuen synagoge many good catholike king many general councells yt euident yea blasphemous lie saint heauē say ye doe al saint faythful christiās hath bene church euer visour ye put vppon church one come cheif poynte knowe church temple hierusalem iustified meane continuall succession without interruptiō bishop sea rome al openly knowen catholik church maynteyning faith ye namely boke impugne wil easely appeare church howe vnperfytte definition lacketh one infallible marke whereby ye may sone disseuer false true church wytte knowē succession bishop age age place christened worlde al worde catholike importeth therfore haue omitted bicause dede catholik churche bicause markes vniuersalyte antiquite knowen succession doe vtterly wante call churche el haue markes haue procure pray horne one brethern prouoke al matter doe answere fortresse first fayth set forth annexed history venerable bede let one al disproue reason brought psalmes prophet ghospel cā wherby clerly proued church cal papistry must true church christ speake vpon confidence owne doinges doe sincerely acknowleadge simple base vpon confidence cause doe assuredly knowe pointe stronge al heretical assaultes shal make shall neuer able shake thus wheras catholik church requireth fek sheweth cōmunion saynts one doctrine one fayth sacrament thing lack cōmuniō participatiō one fayth doth bewray church sore fayne would ye salue howe euidēt howe notorious lye ye force passīg ād shameful impudēcy vaunt self newe ghospel attonement agreemēt religion seing euidēt al world lutheran zuinglians dagger poynte hot cōtentiō sacramētary matter church nowe england catholike saxonicall germanical church hereticall contrarywise luther church catholik church heretical howe ye bragg ye doe nowe agree consent vnyte catholyk fayth necessary doctrine home much say neuer time seinge late one owne protestant bishop opē parliamēt stood boke article lately set forth agreed vpō cōuocation seing sayd boke • ed vp confirmed parliament reiected perpetual shame horn holy brotherhood yet howre tragedy horrible dissension lasteth euen first foundation ragged ghospell lowe country brabant flaundres know casenevves flaūdre • horn brethern shortly certify newes towne antwerpe brother sacramentaries geneua theire church fairly built lutheran also theire church euident eye owne countremen marchants ther beare witnesse agreement horne must eche haue church parte seuerall preacher parted congregation one muste called martinistes church martin luther called must called caluinists church caluin geneua forth came point antwerpe caluinistes tooke armes prince xiij marche last thursday worthy monyment holy profession wil knowe cause forsoth daye forenoone certain brethern number 200 vpward slayne fielde beside number drowned ryuer taken aliue nigh antwerpe power lady regent said brethern great number made profession also certain dayes put practise range aboute countrie ease al church churchman good mary yet conscience iniuring laye man quicke iustice done vpon open robber theues holy brethern sect abyding foreseing yf pageant longe played partes like followe moued immediatly said take armes prince antwerpe require kays gate church catholikes disposed pleasure expulsion al religious person priest c thing graunted vnto gouernor town vpon dayes deliberation al thinges might done quietly thus space ij nightes one day ruled al roste antwerpe outrage small season committed namely vpon poore grey frier whose knowen vertues irked aboue al order let passe saterday x marche morning whē brethern sacramētaries horn contynuing stil armes ād gapīg hourely satisfying gredy appetite thought presently become lordes riche towne sawe sodenly armes brauely strongly appointed catholike marchāts italian spanyardes portugalles burgunyons ād antwerpians selues also sawe horne great greefe word may ful wel prelat alcoran yt horible talke yt vnwonte talke best new gospelling generatiō euē apostle thē luther maketh accompt turke many christiā prince ād preached ād wrote yt lawful christian kepe anye warre namely warre turkes resist god visitīg iniquites thē one article defendeth church rome yt writen turk hearing theis doinges diuisiō brought christēdom liked well enquiring age heard fifty yeres old would ꝙ turke yonger tyme shoulde perhaps one come luther shoulde fynde good lord whē luther heard blessed selfe saied god saue good lorde yea euen day luther hath lib 5 claudio monerio make withstād turke saieth knightes rhodes nothing graf heauenly father neuer graffed therefore owght plucked vp roote let man nowe merueill yf turkes prosper againste christiās seing hath suche frendes home amonge selues wherof horne one least goliath much worse desperatly arrogantlie defying reuiling host liuing god whole catholike churche much vilanously trayterously sayd wicked philistian sworen professed enemy people god therefore therein kinde professing selfe friēd also captaine christian army place occupie considered beare thereunto deuelish philistian harte turkish christian penne hath vttered yet yf ye proued thing answere derogation pope authority religion mainteineth men eares woulde lesse haue glowed heare talke turkishlie haue dede great brauery talke horrible woordes withowt substantiall proufe matter ye take hande yea ye rather ouerborne beaten downe number owne allegation authority place iob ye alleage hypocrite hope shall perishe doth touche fekenham fellowes yt touche blessed man iob baldad vntruely charge yt ye doe baldly vntruely charge nowe catholikes therwith catholiks haue almost one thousand yeres quietly possessed enioyed faith realme ye peuishely prowdly call popery religion ye professe hath yet continewed vnder anie one prince tenne yeares together miracle ye worke none though many wōders ye worke procedinges altogether wondered neither lyfe sect vertuouse learning greate either wyse men suche haue feare god may sodenly drawen theire aunciente catholike faith ye may binde prince nowe lyuing theire successours suche turkish answere reasonable demaunde may wise mainteyne faith notoriously commonly mainteyned englande almost thousande yeares ere ye borne feckenhās reasonable demaūd vppon affirmation moste certainly assuredly know highnes minde therein issue matter seeing meaning othe expresse word doe purport seing l well vnderstand highnes meaning therein thereby righte sence certaine iudgmēt must referre yt discrete consideratiō indifferēt reader yet muche know wil say vnderstande suche haue seueral time cōmunicatiō sayde fekenhā emong thinges conference heard fekenhā say touching theis resolution hath thē daniel thē secretary horne hand writing redie shewed tymes yt yt likely daniel wil testifie truth case shoulde required whose hand writing fekenhā saieth hath also certaine thinges copied yet euent thing come vncertaine let v imagine vnlikely case daniel wil deny forsaied writing hād thē horne much sharply vehemētly crie resolution doth none lyke forged false feyned maliciouse much like matter laieth forth defence nowe suerly though fekenham lyke haue therbye great preiudice principal matter whether resolution true false principal point neither greatly bettered much hindred yet fekenhā perchaunce greatly impayre honesty good name therby let v thē said thinck vpō worst whether fekenham hath ye haue heard much good defence principall pointe may distresse fynde good reliefe defending sauing vpright honesty ye wil perchaūce good reader thinck fekenhā hard ād strayt case yt great difficulty find apparāt honest help yet al ther good great helpe hāde wil bolde self one take vppō self make sufficient proufe resolution fekenhams horne owne yf secretary serue wil bring forth one witnes shalbe somwhat nerer horne shall shiftes euer shall make refuse mayster horne selfe worse man thoughe priuie certaine passed betwixt horne fekēham waltham yet contentes printed answere fekenham assured consequentlie resolution thinges shewe vniuersal comprehension meante withowt exception yf ye excepte take away thinge yt theis owne word horne generall peremptory wordes statute especially precise exposition adioyned thervnto expresly geue vnto quenes mai simple parted authority cheifest principaleste general vniuersal authority al thinges cause whatsoeuer preach minister sacrament lose bynde aswell matter euident theis thing spiritual ecclesiastical ye attribute without exception haue declared owne word supremacy quene al cause thinges spirituall possible necessary consequent ye doe also attribute supremacy cause ecclesiastical rehersed think yowe horne fekenhā fellowes may take othe sauf conscience think though pope authority realme quenes mai might haue large ample authority holy scripture playn consider thema contradiction irrecōcileable horne attributing quenes maie supremacy al spiritual cause thing without exception yet self excepting diuerse thing spiritual geuing supremacy cleargy woulde fayne know lately ruffled freshly oppositiō contrary relatyue priuatiue disparatyue proposition contrary subcontrary subalterne cōtradictory yf man man may fynd fowle contradiction thē laye booke say first fol 104 b fine adde supremacy spiritual cause thing shewe vniuersall comprehensiō without exception yf ye except take away thing hereof ariseth vniuersal affirmatiue al spiritual cause without exceptiō vnder supreme gouuerment prince item say fol 96 b feede church god worde minister christes sacramētes bind lose fol 97 king queenes ād prince may neither doe clayme take vpon stande opposition spirituall cause without exceptiō vnder supreme gouernemēt prī ce contrary spiritual cause vnder supreme gouerment prince subalterne contradictorycontradictory subalterne spiritual cause vnder supreme gouerment prince subcontrary spiritual cause vnder supreme gouernement prince appereth two proposition stāde extremest kind al opposition contradiction though poore sely insufficient shifte make resolution yet beste ye may nowe fynde qualifie mitigate general word statute dede general peremptorie may wise borne without qualification nowe notoriouse qualification made quenes maie iniunctions men take general clause largely collect thereby king quenes realm may challēge authority ād power ministerie diuine office church doth agree resolution therefore cause worlde ye deny say falsly slaunderouslye fayned vpō fekēhā vttering owne peuish cauillatiōs ye say vnder name resolutiōs nowe though necessary interpretatiō moderatiō yet doth take away scruple remaineth staying fekenhā taking said othe interpretatiōnote made acte parliament statute neither doth acte statute referre self iniunctions made qualificatiō restrayning thinge acte braunche thereof cōtayned doth horn book neither hath iniūction lawe realme force restrain weakē mollifie rigour generality acte parliamēt case yet ther remain many great scruple namely swearing cause apperteineth ad externum publicum forum externall publike courte defined saith antonius authority povver declare lavv geue sentence iudge controuersies pertayninge courte vvhat euery man righte summe doo thinges iustice dooth require accordinge lavves ioannes quintinus defineth iurisdiction effect openeth nature therof plainely saying iurisdictiō office authority declare law admynister iustice equity gouern people right ād lawes whā name office saith meane iurisdictiō hath selfe necessity declare lawe office euery man bound doo declare lawe exercise iudgementes wherevppon commeth iurisdiction meaneth iurisdiction hath name called exercising iudgementes iudgementes exercised onelye thē haue iurisdictiō power iudge iurisdiction consisteth contention debating matter courte iudgements authority iudge dooth discende nowe 567 567 vntruthe quintinus speaketh temporall iurisdiction ecclesiasticall prince alone whome power vertue 568 568 vntruthe antonius falsified speaketh midle▪ plainly confutinge horn purpose pardone faultes chaunge mitigate penaūce enioyned confessed faultes condemne heretiques writinges examine men writinges euer set foorth published due examination iudge whether conteyne sounde pestilent doctrin ordeine decree lawes ceremony rytes constitute bisshoppes church minister also depose degrade make irreguler vnhable haue holy order determine illegitimation personnes maryage bestowe ecclesiasticall benefice exact tythes annates many thinges may lavvfully doone haue povver cohybitiue iurisdiction saith properly signified name certayne parish curate yet vnlesse submitte self parrochial priest open vnto synnes neuer losed confesse priuy secrete fault forced owne conscience vnlesse cōfesse thē absolued cōfession excommunicatiō belonging neither king bishoppe haue commission church hearing cause external publyke cowrte heape folly lie first authour doth diuide cohibityue iurisdiction yt doth euidently appeare properly apperteine prince bishop whole church congregation fonde folish frantyk imagination horne euen also author antonius booke largely prouethm horne daūger premunire farre heresy perchaunce farre premunire meane maister horne churche whole churche assemble together meane generall councell whiche dede representeth whole churche shall haue man excommunicated suche councells fewe syth christiā fayth first receaued haue bene assembled yet fewe diuerse haue alredy excōmunicated heresy ye mainteyn yf ye meane particular church party shall denounced excommunicate must haue men womē iurisdiction surelie marueilouse wōderfull interpretatiō horne vrgeth fekenhā swere beleueth consciencesee absurdity horne expoū ding othe prince supreme gouernour cause ecclesiastical addeth ye haue heard wordes must takē without limitatiō exceptiō yet selfe excepteth chief thing cause ecclesiastical wherby man may much better cōclude swere cōtrary prince supreme gouernour al spiritual cause surelie imagine defende prince supreme ruler al cause ād yet abridge authoritie many cause much like one say affirme man king yet able cōmaund man prison offence king ther warre cōmaund man serue king yet businesse stur disorder people neither punish thē make decree proclamatiō rebel premiss true wil follow deede king surely horne thinke haue said ye aduenture far daūgerously whē part touching iurisdiction ye restraine limit statute geueth authorising al maner iurisdictiō prince yea ānexeth vniteth croune secōd cohibitiue ōly kind visitatiō reformatiō shal prince make ecclesiastical authority take away authority excōmunicat al ecclesiastical visiters haue ād euer also expresly belōgeth secōd kind cohibitiue iurisdictiō make depēd prince author antoniꝰ haue shewed cōsider horn whether fekēhā may iustly say deal yl word act expres vnkīdly meaning prince ād state wel remedy interpretation directe contrary reason manifeste wordes statute statute selfe may eluded ye may owne absolute authority spoile supreame head one cheif pointe power ecclesiastical yea cohibitiue iurisdictiō woulde seme graūte pretie newly coyned distinction prince like ye woulde haue yt good currāt mony meane two kindes cohibitiue iurisdiction suppose shall neither founde good diuine boke temporall lawe englande yet woulde fayne heare good conuenient proufe whie seconde cohibitiue ye call yt remayneth prince onely first remaine excommunicatiō part thereof remaineth prince also would know farder whē euer iurisdictiō takē away frō prīces must restored verely neuer could neuer takē away much lesse restored thē right euer belonged thē shew horne yf al study cōferēce frendes one exāple catholik prince either englād al world beside gaue bishop cōmissiō secōd cohibitiue iurisdictiō ye call specified exāples self reherse antonius wil geue one whole twelue moneths edvvard 6 dei grat c reuerēd thomae cant archiepisc etc quando quidē omnis iuris di • ēdi authoritas atque etiā iurisdictio omnimoda tā illa quae ecclesiastica dicitur ꝗ secularis à regia potestate velut à supremo cap c dat 7 die mēs feb 1546 regni nostri primo ye possible stretche without bursting ioyne ought conclude qua verò imperator constantinus obseruantia erga professionem fidei nostrae fuerit niceph li 7 cap 46 abundè illud quoque testatur quòd clericos omnes constitutione lata immune liberos que esse permisit iudicium que iurisdictionem eos episcopis si quidem ciuilium iudicum cognitionē declinare vellēt mādauit quod episcopi iudicassent id robur authoritatem sententiae omnino habere debere decreuit firma quoque immutabilia esse voluit quae synodis constituta essent quae ab episcopis iudicata forent vt ea â magistratibus rempublicam administrantibus militarique quae sub eis essent manu exequutioni mandarentur que ad rem collata perficerentur constituit thing also saieth nicephorus doth abundantly testifievvhat maner iurisdiction cōstantin gaue bishopes honour reuerence beare toward faith ordeyned lawe making clergie shoulde free exempted frō paying tribute case would refuse iudgement temporall magistrate bishop haue iurisdictiō vpon geue sentence cause sayed episcopall iudgement haue ful strength authority ordeined also thinges decreed synode bishopes stande stronge immutable bishoply iudgement put execution ciuil magistrate helpe suche souldiers vnderneath stretche nowe horne conclusion ye without bursting haue lawe constantine clergie may choose whether wil answere matter euer laie man may wil cause matter deuolued bisshop neuer word ecclesiastical matter constātine geueth bishop iurisdiction neither one woorde bishoppes neither summon councelles make ecclesiastical lawes without prince consent plaine ordinaunce lay magistrate shal see synodical decree shall put execution wherby contrary conclusion ye mainteine answere well appeareth prince part onely see ecclesiasticall decree made bishop kept put vre haue necessarie consente allowing disallowing appeareth also euidently eusebius writing constantine sort euseb li 4 cap 27 de vita constant quae ab episcopis publicis conuentibus editae erant regulae sua consignabat confirmabat authoritate signed confirmed authoritie suche canon rule bisshoppes assembly decreed though without royall assente canon shoulde haue beene voide authoritie woulde make folke beleue eusebius writeth place ne reliquarum gentiū principibus liceret quae ab eis decreta essent abrogate intent lawful prince nation abrogate refuse bishop decree reason addeth reus vel • cursis temporum curriculis siue cum negotium peroratur siue cum iam coeperit promi sentē tia si iudiciū elegerit sacrosanctae sedis • tistitis ilico sine aliqua dubitatione etiam si par right legatine right metropolitane ād may visit twyse yere visitours muste beginne visitation solemne masse holy ghost bishoppe euery ordinary visitour must beginne visitation cathedrall churche chapter must come church visiteth first kneele downe pray deuoutly chieflie directing eies mind place wherein honourable sacramēt christes body hiddē kepte matter canō lavve visitatiō parte visitour ought view diligētly whether place wher sacramēt kept cleane wel garnished close eucharist holy chrysme ought kept shut vnder locke key must see great lightes waxe geue light place thē must visit place holy reliquies ād baptisme search diligētly māner place ād whēther kepte shut besides muste visit aultars litle chappelles must eies viewe whole church whether cleāly cleane thē must visit vesselles churche vestymentes whether cleane kepte cleane place ought whether vestimētes ouermuche worne brokē case visitour shal finde suche vestimētes vncleane rēte cōsumed occupying muste burne thē fire cause ash buried place whereby ther passage wise let suffer saith socius purse like thinges worldly vse made cope tunicles last al let suruey house possession belonging churche bishop dooth visit also bisshop enfantes cōsecrate hallow church visitour also shall enquire examine whether mā knowe beleeue fame sexten treasurer vesture keeper hath well saufly kepte vessel vestimentes thinges ornamentes churche masse bookes grayles antiphoners legendes thinges appointed diuine seruice whether thing moueable vnmoueable diminished whome wherefore whan sorte whether diligently present dirigees dead whether vesture keeper sexten keepe warelie cleanly churche eucharist reliques fount churchyardes suche thing shal examine priestes countrie saying mass lette euerye visitour vnderstande saith mine authour greatest question controuersie betwixt three rurall personnes priestes vvherof tvvo stroue vvoordes consecration one affirming vvordes pronounced thus hoc est corpus meus hoc est corpus thinke haue said corpum meum tvvo chose thirde prieste vvho vvas taken better learned arbitour decide high question vvhose ansvvere vvas selfe stoode euer doubtfull question therfore steede vvordes consecration alvvaies vse saye one pater noster furthermore visitour must enquire vvhether laity make confession yeare receiue euchariste easter vvhether slovve denie paie vseth haue trained reader idle talkem horne able ansvvere fekē hās 2 allegation dissembleth altogether nothing purpose like craft ye make yt thirde pointe fekenham speaketh lawes order made apostle gaue precept thessa lonians yet writeth epistle referreth thē former knowledge deliuered doctrine word mouthe otherwise yf ye wil precisely vrge matter must lōger cal old law law moses must lōger seruante moses god thāked thing wil stande together wel inough good cōstructiō diuers relatiō neither cōtrary thē whē christ said doctrine doctrine father sent yf cōsider prīcipal author lawes thē thei god ordināces ād paul apostle whose graciouse inspiratiō ād suggestiō wer made paule ād apostle ministersa distinctiō noted god lavves church lavves ād respect may called lawes euen minister ministery truly forgeue remitte sinne must yet cōsider two thing first lawes churche properly called god lawes apostle set forth holy scripture christe selfe taught thē concerning baptisme holy eucharistia thinges lawes apostle set forth suche receiued christes hāds mouth holy spirite ascension whiche cause called christes ād god lawes apostle al authority make suche lawes hima differē ce betvvene apostle ordinance properly called god ordinance called also lawes apostle namely made first coūcel hierusalē fekenhā alleageth purpose betwixt two ther great differēce christ gaue selfe fewe precept matter onely necessary saluatiō therfore may humaine authority infrīged abolished precept apostle touching gouernaūce churche though man cā priuate authority breake thē yet may august 118 ad ianuar et ideo non praecepit quo deinceps ordine sumeretur vt apostolis per quos ecclesias dispositurus erat seruaret hunc honorem many thē authority church abolished namely made certain special respectes cōtinewe euer time decree apostle made hierusalem touching eating puddinges thinges strangeled see sabboth day turned sonday see though christ celebrated holy maundy blessed eucharistia night gaue yt disciple supper kindes yet church vseth fasting lay mē vnder one kinde thoughe christe cōmaunded v receiue man dispense withall yet maner fashion saieth augustin cōmaūded nothing reserued honour apostle whō intēded directe church therfore also toke order yt especially paule among corinthian according promised ibidem vnde intelligi datur quia multū erat vt epistolae totum illum agendi ordinē insinuaret quē vniuersa per orbem seruat ecclesia ab ipso ordinatum esse quod nulla morum diuersitate variatur fekenham speaketh one thīg h reasoneth agaīst thing wil dispose thing come place fekenham groundeth self vpō therevpon augustine thinketh whiche vniformely generally vsed throughout christendome touching order administration sacrament haue ben ordeined paule could conueniently prescribe appoint epistle ye see though true order lawes may called god ordinaūces lawes yet may also well called lawes ordinaunces apostle thus fekenhams argument standeth ful force euery way talke concerning lord supper quite purpose tell v god law paule appointed saide epistle corinthian yet ye reason fekenham speaketh thing tooke order epistle thing toke order comming whereof said caetera cùm venero disponam thing wil set order come done without writing many thing also deliuered tradition thessalonian fekenham rehearseth paule done fond conclusion without warrant lay person neither ordinaunce praying preaching head vncouered proprely god law bene indispensable fellowes preache cappe heades nede thinke vpon good answeare violating god law wemen come church maried head open whiche might suffred directly god law though paul geueth reason superioritie subection seemeth custome maner proper iewes yet among romaine gentils paules time also throughout al christendome daie opening discouering heade token subiection duetifull honour magistrate superiours wherefore consider scripture well shall finde paule apostle gaue many precept epistle written gospell nothing mentioned ordeined lutheran conclusion wil appeare starke false dangerouse say vide heptacolō l campestri cōtra luther apologiam 1523 paul gaue owne lawes beside ghospel god ordinaunces comprehended within ghospell againe paule whether present taught worde absent writing neither wrote spake receiued lorde last al tradition paule speaketh doctrine ghospell horne said lutheran dangerous conclusion rule woulde frustrate al lawes church luther grādsir expressely cōprehended writen ghospell beeing put apostle made lawes ordinaūces foūd recorded gospel say authoritie prelate churche time hereafter take vpon make lawes expressed gospel mete therfore wicked sequele ād detect lewd cōclusion wil shortly touch moe exāples lawes ordinaunces infallible sound right holsome v therefore vndoubtedly obeyed beleued wherby ouerthrowē horn damnable wicked conclusion affirming apostle haue made lawes besides ghospel god ordinaunces comprehended paulus diaconus saith nicephorus others socrates though write otherwise yet credit lesse knowen haue missereported thing namely matter athanasius arrius contrary writer also noted ignorance euagrius ecclesiasticall writer story ephesine coūcel litle cause charge fekenham misreporting self forsaking consent many folowe one rest fekenham folowed consent best writer second point sayd tripartite hath euen fekenham doth alleage tripart ca 12 li 7 vt dignaretur ad dogmatis emendationē interesse paul diac quatenus dignaretur ad dogmatis emēdationem interesse hath paulus diaconus yt would please hym present wronge opiniōs might reformed 3 point also fekenhā swarueth nothing sayd tripartite nay sayth horne dewe circumstance set forth story nicephorus rightly vnderstode emperours meaning declare sayd lawfull meant lighte easie matter occupied busines care cō men welth paul diaconus mthi cum subiecto populo de huiusmodi negotijs curiosè agere fa nō est vt ergo videtur vobis sacerdotibus facite search matter howe proue nicephorus late writer vnderstand meaning better paulus diaconus lyued least fowre hundred yeares nicephorus writeth thus lawfull people curiously medle suche matter wherfore doe ye priest ye shal thinke good thinke nicephorus priuy themperors right meaning tripart lib 7 ca 12 mihi cū vnus de populo sim fa non est caet epiphanius translatour medicamenta suscipiamus tripart li 7 ca 8 theodor li 4 ca 6 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 eutropius ibidem gratias tibi ago • mine quia huic vir • ego quidē co • mmisi corpus tu autem anima whether cōsider answere answer made electiō ambrose shal fynd al one sort chose ye saith thēperour bishop bishop millane whō gouern empire may sincerly submit head ād whose admonitiōs whē fraylty mē wont trespasse may necessity recieue physitions medecine whē bisshops would haue sette ouer choise appointment newe bisshop wise godly prince nay sayth enterprise worke passeth vocation degree ye indewed grace god shyne brightlie light may much better make election emperour also vnderstanding ambrose chosen sayd thanke thee lord god hath pleased thee commit men sowles meaning ambrose whō cōmitted dispute ād iudges ambros lib 5 epistola 32 arrian bishop auxencius whome ambrose answered sir father onely say wordes ordeyned law matter touching fayth ecclesiastical order ought iudg neither vnequal office vnlike right theis word rescript law priest iudges vpon priestes yea priest otherwise accused examined manner lyfe would bisshops iudges wherfore owne lawe may best serue interpretation answere made bisshops hellespontus premiss declare euidently themperours meaning thought properly belong bishop intermedle affayres ecclesiasticall neither doth nicephorus thing hinder purpose saith wil wel stand sozomenus probable emperour sayd yt holy scripture one place supplieth defect also chronicler perchaunce ye sawe self therfore ye runne accustomable reason yt bulwork prince authority call councels bishop else say neaded haue craued licence themperour wherein answer neaded ayde oportunyte time place tymes bishop haue wrought calling councels prince assistāce time arrians heretiks bearing sway worlde yt great wisedome attempte councell without notice geuen prince consente thereunto namely considering persequutions catholikes late suffred vnder arrian emperour constantius theire decree could effectually executed rebelliouse heretyks cōtemned excommunication al ecclesiasticall iurisdiction neither selues coulde safely quietly assemble together without speciall ayde prince saying learned difference betwixt emperour priest first horne findeth faulte maister fekenham theod lib 5 c 18 vntruely reporteth storie theodosius case true reporte meanes wrested serue fekenhams purpose whit true yet could conclude ambrose forbad theodosius thentrance chauncel bishopes haue power make lawes decree theyr flockes cure exercise seconde cohibitiue iurisdiction nowe perceyue horace saying true breuis esse laboro obscurus fio while men seke breuitie fal obscuritie perchaunce horne might haue saied truelie fekenham saieth fekenham maketh misreporte storie sayeth verie plainely falsely therefore supplie defecte shape horne plaine ful answere wil litle open storie story theodosius emperour ambrose openedthe people thessalonica sedition vprore slewe certaine magistrate wherevppon theodosius though otherwise good verie temperate man al doinges entred great rage choler commaunded people citie destroyed armie furiousnes without anie consideration slewe suche chaunce firste mette withal citizen straungers foreners giltie niceph li 12 cap 40 41 theod lib 5 cap 18 vngiltie certaine tyme chaunced emperour came millane hys custome repayring churche ambrose mette hym forbadde enter moste vehementlie reprouing hym sayed shawghter asking howe coulde finde conscience eyher lyfte vp hys handes god defiled suche foule murther receyue holie bodie christe receyue hys mouthe preciouse bloude christe whose furiouse ragnge commaundemente muche bloude bene shedde wherefore woulde emperour shoulde turne home againe shoulde pacientlie suffer bondeof penaunce emperour enioyned ambrose god heauenly sentence allowed meaning sentence excommunication emperour one browght vppe goddes lawes obeyed hym weapinge teares departed continued eight monethes neuer came thys churche receyued sacramente christes bodie solemne feast christmasse nowe come great heuines sorowe mihi porro non modò id tangere licet verum etiam coelum ipsum clausum est neque enim diuini illius oraculi non memini quod disertis verbis statuit quaecunque sacerdotibus dei ligata fuerint terris ea etiā coelis certa esse ligata consider euery poore begger might goe churche onelie shutte owte full bitterlie complayned moned selfe excluded onelie churche heauen also well remember christe sayde plainlie euer bownde earthe goddes priestes shoulde bownde also heauen lengthe sent ruffinus noble man entreat ambrose went self neither yet would presume enter vntill ambrose absolued losed bōdes te autem oro vt vincula mea soluas et mox tuae vero ò vir diuine id est operae indicare mihi temperare sacrae medicinae remedia humbly penitently craue handes offering hym selfe receyue suche farder penaunce ambrose shoulde enioyne hym wherevpon ambrose enioyned penaunce make lawe suche capitall sentence iudgmentes shoulde seame made extraordinarilye contrarye common order custome themperours put execution til 30 dayes sentēce meane prince might yf nede better aduise selfe either moderation abolishing cōmaundement law presently made subscribed theodosius handes doth day remain sene code vide cod theod li 9 tit 40 lib 13 cod iustin lib 9 tit de poenis si vindicari emperour lēgth reconciled suffered enter church went vp chauncel offer remained willinge receiue sacramēt christes bodie emperours wonte doe ambrose sent deacō warne depart body churche inwarde temple place reuelation encourage hym therto confirme selfe declareth herein doinges agreable teachinges taught catholikes excommunication perteyneth bishopes ād multitud bishop office sayth maybe heale canckered foystered soores may cut perniciouse rotten partes quite true principle bisshops neede looke none warrant excōmunicate man deserueth excōmunication prince neither putting case ye falsely head church therfore either muste take thys vnnatural monstrouse head officiorum lib 2 ca 27 sic episcopi affectus boni est vt optet sanare infirmos serpentia auferre vulnera adurere aliqua non abscindere postremò quod sanari non potest cum dolore abscindere ye sette two heades vpon one bodie ye muste graunte authoritie excommunicat maruell preaching teaching true sure ye make learned men theodosius could espie ye bene elbowe haue enspired whith litle newe diuinitie ye might haue wonderfullie eased woful harte perchance might haue proued doctrine haue worne labour pope triple croune theodosius theodosius learned lesson would haue shifted wel inough felfe neded haue pined away many moneths cōtinual mourning lamentatiō suerly yf ye tolde horne would haue takē ye lier heretike haue sayed feare pronounced bishop onely hath therto ordinary deuotiō life cō formable god lawes none authority al therefore time excommunicated froward mōk hauing none authority therto would neither eat argumente ciuil magistrate heade churche ergo bisshoppes may make lawes maister fekenham neuer yet yll aduised ouersene frame madde argumentes argumente cometh fresh newe hammered owne forge parte man woulde reason thus bishoppes haue power binde loose ergo haue power make lawes order decree c reason amisse seing iudgement learned vnder power binding loosing power making lawes contayned also reason forceth haue skill make lawes order directing men conscience whose whole study office consisteth instructing refourming men conscience maister fekenham doth reason thus blasphemy call prince heade church ergo maister fekenham saufe conscience take othe supremacy prince supreme head againe prince hath authority iurisdiction binde lose excommunicate ergo fekenham persuaded swere statute annexeth vniteth al iurisdiction prince swere prince supreme gouernour cause ecclesiastical childish matter horne leaue fonde childishe dealing make v directe answere argument fekenham proposeth soyle well nowe good felowship horne feckenhams frendes youres catholikes protestant caluin gently excuseth wishing matter forgottē attributing rather want dewe consideration zele willfull malice sinnefull cōmentum doltish deuise say caluin bemoning matter betrayeth meaning maner perdy bemone papistes protestant nedes must whome caluin calleth blasphemous note good reader shiftes fellowes haue pressed see truthe nowell laieth al fault false reporter caluin pitied felowes inconsiderat zele pitieth caluin againe incōsiderat beleuing false reporter fol 127 foolish pitie nowells part vnsauerly soluteth obiection leaue dorman doubt sufficiently discouer exceding foly herein thus nowell shifte hath horne forsothe full wilely closely stealeth cleane away matter self framing feckenham argumente whiche basest logicioner hundred woulde ashamed lo vtter thus folie one side crafte side willfulnes ouercometh heresie contineweth obiection vnanswered yet presse litle haue eies shut thē light shal vnderstād iohn caluin offended brethern englād also germany yea neighbor attributing prince spirituall gouernemēt horn auoucheth fol 14 principall parte prince royall power booke leafe noted saith sed interea sunt homines inconsiderati qui faciūt illos nimis spirituales caluin vbi suprà et hoc vitium passim regnat germania etiam regionibus nimium grassatur et nunc sentimus quales fructus nascantur ex illa radice quòd scilicet principe et quicunque potiuntur imperio putent se ita spirituales esse vt nullum sit amplius ecclesiasticum regimen et hoc sacrilegium apud eos grassatur quia non possunt metiri suum officium certis legitimis finibus sed non putant posse se regnare nisi aboleāt omnem ecclesiae authoritatē sint summi iudices tam doctrina quàm toto spirituali regimine meane vnaduised person doe make thē meaneth lay prince spirituall ouersight rayneth germany countres also procedeth ouermuch nowe feele fruytes springe vp roote verely prince al beare rule think thē athan epist ad solitariam vitam agentes hosius episcopus cordubensis qui synodo nicenae primae interfuit sic habet sicut testatur athanasius aduersus constantium imp si istud est iudicium episcoporum quid commune cum eo habet imperator sin contrà ista mini caesaris conflantur quid opus est hominibus titulo episcopis quando à condito aeuo auditum quando iudicium ecclesiae authoritatem suam ab imperatore accepit aut quando vnquam pro iudicio agnitum plurimae antehac synodi fuerunt multa iudicia ecclesiae habita sunt sed neque patres istiusmodi re principi persuadere conati sunt nec princeps se rebus ecclesiasticis curiosum praebuit nunc autem nouum quoddam spectaculum ab ariana heresi editur conuenerunt enim haeretici constantius imperator vt ille quidem sub praetextu episcoporum sua nziāzenus sermonede dictis hieremiae ad iulianum imperatorem putas ne patimini vt verū vobiscum agam suscipitis ne libertatem verbi libenter accipitis quod lex christi sacerdotali vos nostrae subiecit potestati atque iustis tribunalibus subdit dedit enim nobis potestatem dedit principatum multò perfectiorem principatibus vestris aut nunquid iustum videtur si cedat spiritus carni si à terrenis coelestia superentur si diuinis praeferantur humana sed patienter quaeso accipite libertatem nostram scio te ouem esse gregis mei scio te intra sacrum altaria cum veneratione subijci manibus protestation faith taken blessed augustin bookes heretike iulianus thus belieue belieue hold hold teache teache preache preach yeld thē thow shalt yelde doth horne reuell fekenhā hath like answere first denieth place augustine may good sequele gathered bishop may make lawes vse al cohibitiue iurisdiction hauing fekenham fowle euident faulte pretext maye couered thinketh false dealing owne frendes wil take deape dissembler yea rather abhorre open slaunderer belier father manifest mangler alterer peruerter corrupter augustine stede istis cede non caedes yelde thou shalt strike whip hath put istis cede mihi cedes yelde thow shalt yelde saith belike fekenham sticke corrupte maketh flatte thus vseth corrupt maketh neither fro self selfe rolleth augustine sentence layth forth fekēhā euil dealing augustin doth pelagius brittayn monke finally though battel wōne ful conquest made vpon poore fekenham calleth vpon yelde relente mary sir terrible blaste dede blowen maister horne mouth farewell blustering tempest sturred vp newe aeolus seemeth fekenham must nedes ouerblowen vehemency yt yet seeke see foundation original cause broyle al likelihodde fekenham hath founde good apparance great aduantage corrupting wordes augustin man lightly doltish vse foule sluttish shift without cōfort hope matter according old saying cui bono nay saith horn corrupting sentence serueth whit fekenhās purpose doth horne would fekenhā deale fondly opē falshod staine honesty ād whippe trāslate yelde without benefit cause suerly thē worthy aswel loue twise whipped falshod ād ons folly therefore accusation euē tale cui bono vtterly incredible yet yf falsly folishly demeaned self seing toucheth part substance questiō lieth betwixt ād playe yf folish yet vehemēt oratour ād haue sauced oratory ouer much gal ād egernes al blowing blustering great hil bringeth forth nothing poore aesop mouse yet say naughty part manifestly māgle corrupt augustin perchaunce good reader thou dost looke answer fekēham may saue honesty agaīst mighty accusatiō suerly answer may best make redely tel tell meane season vse play part wel otherwise yet somtimes last cast folish disorder hissed clapped multitude shoting thē ād clapping ought waynscot faced mā driuen frō stage hauīg throughout book plaied many foule ād vilanouse part valete ād plaudite plaieth euill worse part hath plaied residewe booke moe example augustins work printed haue sene four first printed basil secōd third paris fourth liōs ād al haue istis cede mihi cedes yeld 1528 fol 1541 1555 fol 1563 8 lib primo cont iul cap 2 medio capitis tom 7 thou shalt yeld later editiō paris readeth text f readeth putteth margent diuerse reading non caedes horne ful peuishly wretchedly would make folke beleue read detestable impudency thē horn crie vpō f poore prisoner outragiouse sort allegatiō place sternely ād fiercely vaūt saying dare ye impudētly say ye preache ād teache whē ye manifestly mangle alter peruerte corrupt saying teache aske saint augustine hath woordes sixe bookes iulian istis cede mihi cedes truth thoughe sayde copyes haue woordes order yet forgetfulnes fekenham hath set booke wil ye see howe wel matter amended horne ruffling blustering self hauing al copy nameth either theis sixe bokes place boke augustine printed shoulde haue text suche tenour doth alleage yet doth horne ye haue hearde though right true yea synne holy ghost reuile fekenham leaueth augustine truely obiected pelagius doth vntruely obiect fekenham euen truely sayd pelagius english monke dead buried saxon entred britanny pelagius died time least theodosius seconde saxon entred realme tyme marcianus witnesseth bede britanny commonly called england pelagius dead lest one hundred yeres beda li • cap 15 polid li 3 christened hundred halfe nowe concerninge matter yt selfe whether coūcels father olde nowe horn haue alleaged especially augustine may truely say said pelagius referre indifferent reader suerly none al may easely appeare diligent reader may iustly say horne ye fayne say say conclude conclude aug li 3 cōtra • ul graunt graunte conclude self denie againe dede ye haue laboured fynd owt reason ye might better vtter self lib 5 case ye shuld nede take suche paynes yf yow shame whether say truely referre thee good reader whole answere wil see cōpendiously proued preface conclusion thirde booke woulde faine breake confutation horne answere augustine testimony sauing doth otherwise excedingly belie augustine may wise altogether passe ouer shamelesse demeanure say horne augustine one father whome reherseth cyprianus ireneus basilius hilarius lib 1 cō tra iulianum ambrosius hieronymus pope innocentius others eyther pope hath superiority matter ecclesiastical prince haue hitherto ye haue browght augustine whose sayinges ye haue filled vp leaues reacheth farther thē prince may lawes punishe suche disobediēte churche lawes whiche thing man doth contende woulde light learning knowledge el grosse ignoraunce palpable darkenesse let fall light whiche side shall happe vppon triall examination made doubt honour shall haue full shewe sufficient proufe made euery vvere vnmann • rlie vvordes spoken mine ovvne table therfore vvould thā say opēly vnto tolde dinner vvoulde shevve minde betvvixt shortly dinner came vp calling gallory house adioining chamber put stil cō tinuāce misorder yea muche vehemēt many time mine absence presence therefore vvilled thenceforth absteine conferring vvith anie man vvise addinge haue chamber al thing necessary vvhat meate vvold competently appoint ovvne diet vvhich ye accordinglie although restraine comming mie table goe much large doon yet keper vvhich vvas ovvn man faire gallory adioyning chā ber opening mie parke excusable ignorāce particular factes al forsake god loue neighbour time rather letted hindered auerted remoued loue duty god synne called venial pardonable acte thereof excludeth v kingdome heauen neither maketh v deadly guilty god sight reason motion frailty light negligence without life lead smodering heate olde fyre originall sinne cleane quenched water baptim quenched say gyltinesse thereof remayne quenched vtterly operation working thereof olde adam worketh still v rebelleth spirite notwithstanding drowned baptisme spirite newe man christ resisteth fighteth daily fight combat best men sometime venially ouercomed though deadly men clere doctrine augustin al learned father alleaged secōd booke iuliā pelagiā ambrose cypriā chrysostome hierom gregorie naziāzene hilarie basil ireneus certain saied alleaged iuliā pelagiā short herein horn behold one direct ād clere sentēce austin cōformable al holy father ād doctours shortly clerely cōfuteth ignorāt cōfusiō venial sinne ād mortal saying euery sinne self mortal alleged al forenamed doctours ād last al place ambrose cōcerning remnāts original sin v doctrine ād melāchthōs deadly mortal sinne thus cōcludeth self ecce quantā no pugnā etc lib 2 cō tra iul pelag 7 fol 213 • fol paris anno 55 behold greate fight cōbat valiaūt souldiar christ ād faithful doctor church meneth amb sheweth v haue sinnes allready dead ād slayne meneth original sinne baptism howe sin dead seing worketh many thing v whē striue many thing fond hurtful desire draw consenters vnto destruction yet suffer yeld vnto combat conflict battail nowe betwene battail▪ betwene good euill betwen nature nature manichee imagined betwene nature synne synne saye already dead yet buried whollly healed howe say sinne dead baptisme also mā sayth ambrose howe yet confesse dwelleth membres worketh v many desire striuing still also ambrose confesseth bicause sinne respect gyltynesse thereof wherein baptisme fast tyed dead yet beinge dead rebelleth vntyl perfect buryal quite healed yet sinne nowe baptisme sorte called sinne made v guilty god bicause gyltinesse adam made synne bicause also rebelling draweth v sin except grace god iesus christ lord helpe v dead sinne rebelle ouercoming v waxe againe alyue reigne mortal body battail fighting toyling longe life tentation vpon earthe nō ide • sine peccato non sumus therefore sinne sed quibus ab illo rebellāte etsi nō laetaliter sed venialiter tamen vincimur cō trahimus vnde quotidie dicamus dimitte nobis debita nostra suche sorte called synne worketh membres contrarying lawe minde longe consent vnto vnlawfull desire motion touching selues remaine alwaies without sinne vntill euill vtterly healed neuer consent euill thinges rebellion euill ouercomed though deadly venially yet ouercomed thinges say contract gette wherby must daily say lorde forgeue v trespass example maried folke pleaesure excede measure necessary generation also continent chaste person stay thoughtes delectation yet determining wicked deede • gerentes decernentis bearinge wicked dede doth determine auerting diligently ought intention minde suche thoughtes yet riddinge selues soone thoughtes one fallē ought thus farre augustin two exāples geueth venial sinne veniall sinnes muste say daily saith lord forgeue v trespass accordīg doctrine teacheth place wher writeth thus sonnes god longe liue mortal life enchi • idio cap 64 rom 8 fight mortalite though truly saied thē many lead spirit god sonnes god yet stirred spirit god doe profit godward sonnes god yet sonnes mē sap 9 crimen peccatū especially reason corruptible bodie molesting thē falle back thē selues ward certain humain motiōs therefore sinne great difference haue largely saied though euery crime terme calleth mortal sinne sinne 1 ioan 1 yet euery sinne crime much say euery venial sinne mortall deadly therefore say dede life holie men long liue mortalite maie founde without crime deadly sinne venial sinne saie haue deceaue selues holy apostle saieth truthe v againe augustin maketh clere differēce betwene crime deadly sinne maketh v sonnes wrath ād betwene venial sinne continewe yet sonnes god holie mē life neuer lacke god forbidde holy men shoulde neuer lacke deadly mortal sinne vpon horne doctrine euerie synne selfe mortall must nedes folow horne lewd spirit holy spirit lerned father farre wide sonder learned melanchthon luther synke filthie heresy howe learnedly pithely fonde lewde doctrine melanchthon luther youres confuted doctour eckius open disputation betwene melanchthon wormes may horne make deinty thinke reade heresye bookes see reade greate cōfusion euen workes melanchthon printed wittenberge tom 4 actis vvor maciensibus fol 650▪ sequent pag 656 fine anno 1564 also shall finde notable place augustine corrupted first luther melanchthon clerely detected pressed doctor eckius melanchthon fayne honourable assembly openly recante say quod ad attinet agnosco male citatum esse owne part confesse wrōgfully alleaged place augustine wrote concupiscence taken away baptisme non vt non fit sed vt non imputetur yt shoulde man baptism baptisme imputed vnto v yf deliberat consent yelded thereto luther ād melāchton mad augustin say sinne takē away baptism cōtinewed stil mā imputed mā feate ād sleight turning cōcupiscēce sin proued imputatiue righteousnes mā neuer iuste good holy accepted though remained stil sinner ād sin alwaies also sinne deadly mortall sinne thinge horne affirmeth auouching euery sinne yt selfe mortal make ende hereof shortly much say euery sicknesse infirmitie disease self death body liueth soule soule liueth god body dieth soule separated soule dieth god gone matter augustin excellently handleth notable worke de ciuitate dei lib 13 cap 23 24 lib 14 cap 4 9 therefore euery disordered affection body killeth hande body longe much vexed deseases infirmites dye yea longe desease reacheth harte roote vital humour hence life springeth longe principle life whole sounde body liueth dieth euery cōuersion soule creature bredeth separation soule frō creatour soule fighteth againste fleshe though fight take blowe yea wounde thē yet sowle recouereth selfe yeldeth wholy fleshe creature cleaueth stil god creatour loueth stil kepeth lawe falleth deadly neyther synneth mortally vntyll geue ouer vice forsaketh god euil men doe without fight combat al good men either al seldom great fight thē good men childrē god nowe become child wrathe perish euerlastingly except repente greate clere distinction betwene mortal sinne venial synne adde though euery synne yt selfe mortal yet also venial purged merites christ yf take venial pardonable remissible graūte euery synne neuer mortall sense venial synne holy ghoste finall impenitēce alonely excepted yf take venial opposite mortal fekenhā toke whē auouched godly ceremony venial synnes may remitted must take yf wil cōtrary fekenhams assertion foule errour venial synne mortal haue proued neither mortal synne venial longe mortall confounding degree synne make mortall stoical barbarous paradoxe opening gate al dissolutenesse licentiousnesse cōtrary truth lerning cōtrary good life good maners semeth agree iumpe luther paradoxe wherein taught defended good worke neuer wel done according mercy god venial sinne according iudgemēt god mortal sinne roffensis cōtra articul lutheri art 31 32 vide cōcil trident sess 6 25 straunge paradoxe fonde fryer beinge lernedly pithely confuted learned holie countreman blessed bishoppe rochester doctour fysher remitte lerned reader place also shall fynde distinction mortall veniall sinne clerely prosecuted againste wicked doctrine luther peuishe assertion horne adde merites christe onely yf meane principal effect vertue wherof workes men auaylable meritorious graūt say wel yf say mortal synne purged merites christ excluding worde al repentance contrition harte confession mouthe satisfaction owne partes ability note foule errour wicked heresye luther grandsir whereby extolle merites christ doe ful peuishly exclude al worke mā yet scripture expressely require concurre merit christ thē selues simply auailable merit christes passiō auaylable ād workes holy ghost geuē vnto v charity poured hart good ād meritorious remēbre horn christ said iewe heretike wicked christiā galat 5 ōly haue faith worketh charity charity cōprehēdeth al maner good work affirme beside fekenham veniall sinne remitted ceremony short answer point bicause largely matter treated allen last booke power priesthod c heare augustin sayth enchiridio within chapter wordes lastly recited euchi • idio c 71 delet omnino haec oratio minimum quotidia • peccata cap 72 made distinction betwene crimen peccatum thus saith de quotidianis autem breuibus leuibúsque peccatis sine quibus haec vita non ducitur quotidiana oratio fidelium satisfacit cōcerning daily short light sinnes without man liueth daily prayer faithefull doth satisfye daily prayer meaneth pater noster chapter expoundeth self againe next chapter teacheth kindes almes dedes vnder almes dedes comprehending al good workes venial sin forgeuē thꝰ saith lōg enumeratiō good work multa ita que genus sunt eleemosynarū quae cū facimꝰ adiuuamur vt dimittātur nobis nostra peccata therfore many kind almes dedes whē doe holpē haue sin forgeuē vnto v nowe saying daily prayer ād doīg almes dedes thought lerned father redeme smaller sinnes bicause sin cōmitted total auersiō frō god creatour mortal venial fraile cōuersiō creature euery good motiō god ward expressed vertuous act thomas par 3 q 87 art 3 redemeth sight god former declinīg frō god reuerēt motiō godward expressed augustin exāples fake sayīg pater noster ānd almes dedes iudgmēt church true christē man ought mystrust also expressed kneeling knockīg brest kissing holy reliks holy ceremony honour god ād saīts redoūdeth hī whose sake honored horn may shortly vnderstād sense catholiks affirme holy ceremony venial sin may takē away thus crosse came frō iesuites feken came good howre occasiō wherof haue discouered vnto lurking heresy ād catholike faith somwhat opened perhaps thē wold wer al haue grace harkē thervnto farder assertiō al mortal syns also venial saue ōly syn agaīst holy ghost new scoured heresy wiclef touched see ye saye mortall sinne sinne holy ghoste howe contrary selfe saying al sinnes mortal yet againe affirming mortal sinne one whereby ye go nere pelagians heresie taking away originall sinne mortall sinne sinne holy ghoste lacke repentance wicleff declareth adam cōmitte mortal sinne died penitently vide aug cōtra iul per totum cōmitted deadly sinne transgression god cōmaundement could transfunde originall sinne kill posteritie braunche pelagian heresie neither wil helpe say synne sauing lacke repentaunce purged merit christ question speake veniall mortall synne howe may taken away forgeuen payne penalty eche owne nature deserueth venial synne deserueth payne tē poral paine mortal sinne deserueth euerlasting paine place exactly discusse matter haue saied onely shew sort errours heresy ye wrap vp closing boke theis fekenham might haue called iustly plaine termes without almost heretike iewel fekenham said ye say sayd neuer able answere doctour harding boke said nothing truth doth well appere indifferent reader labour haue confuted already stronger greater important partes reply haue alredy discried one thowsand manifest errours lie number thinke muster whole confutation remnant come forthe would nowe somewhat saied answere concerning rumour fekenhams subscription recantation suppose knewe whole circūstance matter might easely confute al answere therin yet straunge ye make self rumour knowledge therof man may wel gather go owne booke selfe ministred great occasion suche rumour telling often answere feare reuolte frendes whiche also ende answere fol 2 telling semed resolued fol 130 maner fully satisfied hand ye made relation thereof certaine honourable person finally fol 128 selfe plainely confesse ye sayed fekenham chaunged religion nine tymes yea nintene tymes matter leaue also vnkinde vngentle dealing complaintes againste contrary promisse nowe onely put reader remembramce iesuites whome ye call monkishe iebusites pray withall well consider order trade theire lyues doctrine yea gloriouse issewe hath daylie doth followe thereof comparing doinges doctrine fellowes doubte thinke nothing vile
